name: Blended Scotch TB-BSW6 Year Old Thompson Bros
characters: Figs, Sultana, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Toffee, Coffee
nose: Plum sauce, miso, golden sultanas, cinder toffee and coffee crème patissiere
palate: Golden sultanas, raisin loaf, buttered Jamaica cake, maple and toasted cinnamon
finish: Soft warm spice; allspice, nutmeg and cinnamon, with orange peel and dried figs
reviews: Stunning stuff for the money, might well be my new house dram. Soft, beautifully textural with restrained sherry sweetness. || This is great value for money if you’re looking for a regular sipper at a great price . 46%, natural colour and non chill filtered. I ‘ll definitely be being another bottle. || This is super. Tried it with a friend and had a blind tasting of 4 other drams. This came out tops. Even knocked the socks off 3 Islay malts. In our tasting. || Excellent balanced dram. One of best, new generation blended whiskies on the market, a must try. NK || Great value for a rich tasting scotch. Love it. || Forced to write a review having taken a punt and bought a bottle as a regular inexpensive "sipper". Usually Naked Grouse fills this space in my cabinet, which I find terrific value, and usually can get for near enough £20, and hits those sherry malty notes I find quaffable. However TB/BSW is a far superior product. Very sherried and thick treacle, hitting many of the notes as a GlenAllachie 15, and at half the price. Non chill filtered and no colour added to boot. This really is a great addition to any collection for a fan of big sherry cask influence, with great depth of flavour and complexity, and in my view unrivalled value for money in the sub £35 level. || Excellent liquid and great value! || Reputedly from Edrington stock this is a lovely sherry bomb of a blend. The grain is almost  imperceptible, this tastes more like a classic Speyside sherried malt with all the Xmas cake vibes that entails. After a while open oxidation resulted in a sulphur note that came to dominate proceedings a little so if you're sensitive to that you may wish to swerve this one (minus a star for that). However overall value is excellent!
_text_all: figs sultana cinnamon nutmeg toffee coffee plum sauce miso golden sultanas cinder toffee and coffee cr me patissiere golden sultanas raisin loaf buttered jamaica cake maple and toasted cinnamon soft warm spice allspice nutmeg and cinnamon with orange peel and dried figs stunning stuff for the money might well be my new house dram soft beautifully textural with restrained sherry sweetness this is great value for money if you re looking for regular sipper at great price natural colour and non chill filtered ll definitely be being another bottle this is super tried it with friend and had blind tasting of other drams this came out tops even knocked the socks off islay malts in our tasting excellent balanced dram one of best new generation blended whiskies on the market must try nk great value for rich tasting scotch love it forced to write review having taken punt and bought bottle as regular inexpensive sipper usually naked grouse fills this space in my cabinet which find terrific value and usually can get for near enough and hits those sherry malty notes find quaffable however tb bsw is far superior product very sherried and thick treacle hitting many of the notes as glenallachie and at half the price non chill filtered and no colour added to boot this really is great addition to any collection for fan of big sherry cask influence with great depth of flavour and complexity and in my view unrivalled value for money in the sub level excellent liquid and great value reputedly from edrington stock this is lovely sherry bomb of blend the grain is almost imperceptible this tastes more like classic speyside sherried malt with all the xmas cake vibes that entails after while open oxidation resulted in sulphur note that came to dominate proceedings little so if you re sensitive to that you may wish to swerve this one minus star for that however overall value is excellent

name: Johnnie Walker Blue Label
characters: Rose, Hazelnut, Honey, Smoke, Dark Chocolate, Tobacco
nose: Smooth, silky cereal, syrupy flapjacks, polished oak. Dessicated coconut, then other nutty notes: unsalted peanut, brazil nut.
palate: A silky caress. Unexpectedly strong spicy entry, but always honeyed and rounded by some toasty oak. The honeyed malt is beautifully interwoven around the venerable grain, which must be absolutely ancient.
finish: A perfectly-integrated slow fade of the palate. Mouthwatering grain, and the honey and spices dwindle slowly. Extremely long but still very gentle.
reviews: Un elixir. || Excellent Whisky. Smooth on the palate, easy to drink and exceptionally good. || Not worth the price. Bought it due to all the hype surrounding it and was disappointed. I would prefer a bottle of single malts such as Glenfiddich over it.
_text_all: rose hazelnut honey smoke dark chocolate tobacco octopus monkfish fondue smooth silky cereal syrupy flapjacks polished oak dessicated coconut then other nutty notes unsalted peanut brazil nut silky caress unexpectedly strong spicy entry but always honeyed and rounded by some toasty oak the honeyed malt is beautifully interwoven around the venerable grain which must be absolutely ancient perfectly-integrated slow fade of the palate mouthwatering grain and the honey and spices dwindle slowly extremely long but still very gentle un elixir excellent whisky smooth on the palate easy to drink and exceptionally good not worth the price bought it due to all the hype surrounding it and was disappointed would prefer bottle of single malts such as glenfiddich over it

name: Johnnie Walker Swing
nose: Complex and sophisticated with almost perfumed sweetness. Unquestionably soft and accessible, you are sure to notice the fanciful vanilla and sherry-cask wood notes wafting through.
palate: Smooth and sweet. But its light freshness cloaks a deeper fruitiness, with some smoke and restrained flavors lingering beyond.
finish: A lengthy and rich finish, reverberating with sweetness, completes the movement.
reviews: Certainly overpriced for what it is -- I pick up a fair bit of Cardhu malt on the palate, so if that's a whisky to your liking, you'll enjoy Swing. It's an effortlessly inoffensive blend, nicely balanced and integrated. Nothing really stands out (apart from the glorious nose), but nothing upsets, either. Frightfully easy to drink, tasty, but once again, a bit too bruising to the wallet. My bottles are from pre-2009, so YMMV with the more contemporary bottlings. || I have tried SWING and really liked it. Its taste was outstanding and compares with JW Blue, and I really thought nothing could compare to JW Blue. || I was bought a bottle for a birthday present and not being a whiskey drinker I was very surprised to find only half a bottle left the next morning!! Count me as a convert || Of all the Johnnies, this is the goto swig. || "Nose" (undiluted) Invitingly floral with gentle sherry notes, followed by a wisp of smoke. Malty too. "Palate" (undiluted) Sweet wild honey smeared on dark toast. Light sherry notes (think dark red fruit) make an appearance before a transition to spiced vanilla and butterscotch. "Finish" (undiluted) Sherry still there. Some oak comes to the forefront before fading to a final dark red fruit note (due to the sherry influence) .
_text_all: no description complex and sophisticated with almost perfumed sweetness unquestionably soft and accessible you are sure to notice the fanciful vanilla and sherry-cask wood notes wafting through smooth and sweet but its light freshness cloaks deeper fruitiness with some smoke and restrained flavors lingering beyond lengthy and rich finish reverberating with sweetness completes the movement certainly overpriced for what it is -- pick up fair bit of cardhu malt on the palate so if that whisky to your liking you ll enjoy swing it an effortlessly inoffensive blend nicely balanced and integrated nothing really stands out apart from the glorious nose but nothing upsets either frightfully easy to drink tasty but once again bit too bruising to the wallet my bottles are from pre- so ymmv with the more contemporary bottlings have tried swing and really liked it its taste was outstanding and compares with jw blue and really thought nothing could compare to jw blue was bought bottle for birthday present and not being whisky drinker was very surprised to find only half bottle left the next morning count me as convert of all the johnnies this is the goto swig nose undiluted invitingly floral with gentle sherry notes followed by wisp of smoke malty too palate undiluted sweet wild honey smeared on dark toast light sherry notes think dark red fruit make an appearance before transition to spiced vanilla and butterscotch finish undiluted sherry still there some oak comes to the forefront before fading to final dark red fruit note due to the sherry influence

name: Chivas Regal 12 Year Old
characters: Honey, Vanilla, Apple, Pear, Butterscotch, Heather
reviews: Very mundane. Not bad but far from good. Its got a bite which doesn't bother me of it has a smooth finish. It does not. I can't detect notes of anything like a Speyside is known for no fruit or toffee or anything. And I don't disdain a good Blended Scotch. This just ain't in the toppins. || The worst whiskey I have ever tasted. Yes, someone might call it smooth, but it completely lacks any distinguishing flavors, no character! I really don't know how it can be so popular all over the world. In my opinion, ?ther 12 year old blends like Dewars 12 and Grants 12 are much better with more distinguished aromas and taste. I won't give this even to my worst enemy. || Disgusting all burn and a big blast of alcohol not even worth £ 1 . Had to give 1 star or review not accepted otherwise would give it minus 5 stars .probably not even useful as drain cleaner! || The nose is stewed fruits, mainly apple, red and green. Not much else after that. Same for the taste. Nice and sweet with white pepper at the end. Good price for it though. || Wow fab

name: Johnnie Walker Black Label 12 Year Old
nose: Soft and complex with touches of toasted oak, honey, coconut, and figs.
palate: Spicy with a nice allspice note on top and caramel syrup sweetness underneath.
finish: Hints of lemon-lime citrus develop later, and last through the long finish.
reviews: Johnnie Walker Black Label is one of the iconic blends. If you're a beginner- this is a whisky you should try. Before JWB I tried basic versions of JW, Grant's, Ballantine's. To me JWB was on a different level of complexity. This is not a single malt but it has a very smooth, consistent taste, I get notes of tobacco, oak, some grass, smoky finish. Great on ice or with a bit of water. || Really enjoyed this for a while until it started to give me an after taste of soap. Put me off it after that || Boring, flat and bland. Truly unremarkable. || I wanted to like this, but it's really just all a bit flat. You can tell that the flavours are there but they are so reduced to make this all a bit bland, unfortunately. It could really do with a couple of more points on the alcohol percentage. There is a bit of smoke and a bit of toffee and a bit of oil on the tongue, just not enough of any of those factors. Don't add ice or water, any flavour that is there will be nullified. Maybe I'm being harsh coming from some of the big single malt flavours, but I'm always interested in what the blenders can do. I bought this on offer, to contradict myself, I'll keep it to mix with cola and ice, or even IRN BRU. || I want to rate this three stars, but as soon as you’re out for dinner somewhere that doesn’t have a good selection of scotch JWB becomes a five star expression. Probably the best feature is the perfect 50/50 blend of Islay peat smoke and charred oak barrel smoke. Though, I’m still not a fan of the heavy peatedness. And would prefer the oak char only. Nevertheless, on a lot of ice as it is served in bars and restaurants, this totally hits the spot. It’s completely reliable. For the price, this is impossible to beat. Very good blend of sweet, vanilla, leather and peppered tannins. There really isn’t anything else available that is this versatile. Definitely nothing at this price.
_text_all: cream toffee dried fruit smoke octopus monkfish fondue soft and complex with touches of toasted oak honey coconut and figs spicy with nice allspice note on top and caramel syrup sweetness underneath hints of lemon-lime citrus develop later and last through the long finish johnnie walker black label is one of the iconic blends if you re beginner- this is whisky you should try before jwb tried basic versions of jw grant ballantine to me jwb was on different level of complexity this is not single malt but it has very smooth consistent taste get notes of tobacco oak some grass smoky finish great on ice or with bit of water really enjoyed this for while until it started to give me an after taste of soap put me off it after that boring flat and bland truly unremarkable wanted to like this but it really just all bit flat you can tell that the flavours are there but they are so reduced to make this all bit bland unfortunately it could really do with couple of more points on the alcohol percentage there is bit of smoke and bit of toffee and bit of oil on the tongue just not enough of any of those factors don add ice or water any flavour that is there will be nullified maybe being harsh coming from some of the big single malt flavours but always interested in what the blenders can do bought this on offer to contradict myself ll keep it to mix with cola and ice or even irn bru want to rate this three stars but as soon as you re out for dinner somewhere that doesn have good selection of scotch jwb becomes five star expression probably the best feature is the perfect blend of islay peat smoke and charred oak barrel smoke though still not fan of the heavy peatedness and would prefer the oak char only nevertheless on lot of ice as it is served in bars and restaurants this totally hits the spot it completely reliable for the price this is impossible to beat very good blend of sweet vanilla leather and peppered tannins there really isn anything else available that is this versatile definitely nothing at this price

name: Hankey Bannister Original
reviews: Thoroughly enjoyed it. Nice taste and smell. Not too harsh on the throat, but lovely with a splash of water and a clink or two of ice. Obviously not like a single malt, but drinkable non the less. I will buy again. || Not the worst whisky I have, but I don't like it. It smells OK - honey/caramel switness combined with a fair amount of alcohol and spice. But the teste is disappointing despite the layering. It has spice, a hint of smoke and fruits, but also a dark char and oil notes (in a bed way, like engine oil). Oak opens up in the finish but it quickly disappears leaving you with great amount of alcohol that anesthetized all around in your mouth. Overal, It was an interesting expericence but the next time I'd like to taste a scotch I'll definitely will take someting else in about the same price category. || One of the best whiskies I've had the pleasure of trying || The worst whisky I have ever had the misfortune of drinking. || Not a bad blend for the price at my local store in Taipei.
_text_all: no description no description no description no description thoroughly enjoyed it nice taste and smell not too harsh on the throat but lovely with splash of water and clink or two of ice obviously not like single malt but drinkable non the less will buy again not the worst whisky have but don like it it smells ok - honey caramel switness combined with fair amount of alcohol and spice but the teste is disappointing despite the layering it has spice hint of smoke and fruits but also dark char and oil notes in bed way like engine oil oak opens up in the finish but it quickly disappears leaving you with great amount of alcohol that anesthetized all around in your mouth overal it was an interesting expericence but the next time like to taste scotch ll definitely will take someting else in about the same price category one of the best whiskies ve had the pleasure of trying the worst whisky have ever had the misfortune of drinking not bad blend for the price at my local store in taipei

name: Johnnie Walker Sweet Peat
food_paring: Fish And Chips, Bbq Ribs, Roasted Aubergine
reviews: very enjoyable dram def give it a go || Huge fan of Black & Green Label (the latter hugely underrated), but came across this blend by chance. Really impressed. The balance of the smoke & sweat is great - I suspect Caol Ila is the star here. Lovely notes of caramel & fudge. || The Sweet Peat was a very nice and delicate scotch the peat was suttle and the maltiness was sweet toffee-like with a hint of fruit, apricots. It was very smooth and everything unique about it would fade quickly as you notice it to show other complexities about it. || A lovely blend. Very little peat on the nose but a delightful blend of sherry and peat on the palate all the way through to the finish. A fine addition to the JW brand. || Bought this on a trip to your Covent Garden shop in January and cracked it open on recently. Superb and without a doubt one of the finest blends I've tried. Highly recommended.

name: Johnnie Walker Double Black
characters: Smoke, Oak, Tar, Honey, Apple, Sultana
nose: Fairly light but oily, with dry oak, honey and gently stony smoke.
palate: The flavour is full bodied and complex with the signature Johnnie Walker peat smoke shining brightly through rich raisins and sultanas. Apples, pears and orange zest bring freshness while creamy vanilla and spice bring a softness and sweetness to the tongue.
finish: The long warming finish combines spicy oak tannins and lingering smoke.
reviews: One of my favourite. || Bought it on special here in Australia. Good to drink after a day at work, the oakiness at the finish is worth the 30 quid I paid for it. || 100% satisfaction with any Johnnie Walker whiskey. Gold reserve still remains a firm leader though || It is a great whisky, it is like a less smooth JW Black Label with more smoke, not my first choice but excellent nontheless. || It is a very smooth and delicious whisky
_text_all: smoke oak tar honey apple sultana bbq ribs vegetable tagine burgers fairly light but oily with dry oak honey and gently stony smoke the flavour is full-bodied and complex with the signature johnnie walker peat smoke shining brightly through rich raisins and sultanas apples pears and orange zest bring freshness while creamy vanilla and spice bring softness and sweetness to the tongue the long warming finish combines spicy oak tannins and lingering smoke one of my favourite bought it on special here in australia good to drink after day at work the oakiness at the finish is worth the quid paid for it satisfaction with any johnnie walker whisky gold reserve still remains firm leader though it is great whisky it is like less smooth jw black label with more smoke not my first choice but excellent nontheless it is very smooth and delicious whisky

name: Bell's Original
characters: Mixed Herb, Malt, Heather, Honey, Oak
reviews: Smashing || Seriously, if you drink Scotch and Dry Ginger Ale, this is the prefect mixer!  Why pay any more? || Surprised by how much I enjoyed a dram of Bell's when I tried it for the first time in a long time recently...really enjoyed the smoky, fruity, malty flavours.  Everyone has their own palate and taste and this works for me, especially after a cold walk over the hills on a rainy day. || Pleasantly surprised. I usually drink single malts - Macallan Gold a favourite - but recently thought I'd revisit some of the blended whiskeys I drank many years ago. Haven't drank Bells since the 70s and wasn't expecting too much. But I am actually enjoying it. Certainly excellent value for money. name: Johnnie Walker Gold Label Reserve
food_paring: Fish And Chips, Dim Sum, Turkey
nose: Honey, vanilla cream, sherry-style dried fruits and notes of biscuits.
palate: Luxuriously smooth, creamy and delicately honeyed with lingering waves of wood, fruit and light, sweet smoke. A multi-layered blend of sweet fruits and creaminess that evokes deeper honey tones.
finish: Lingering waves of wood and light west-coast smoke.
reviews: Very good . So happy with it, that I will not exite to place another order when my finances improves. || This with the 18 offer the best value in the range. One of the smoothest whiskies you can buy, with nice traces of toffee, dried fruit (sherry)and hint of smoke from the malt. Made with Clynelish has more depth than the thinner tasting black label. Hence it costs more. But still a good price. Most will struggle not to like this. || Robust nose, fairly full palate. However the finish is bitter - and not very pleasantly so. I believe Black Label is a better choice for the price, and Green Label infinitely better. || This tastes great but doesn't smell very good. The blenders need to make a change or two. The old Gold Label that was an 18 year old was in a different league. || Excellent very smooth . It’s that good my wife drinks it all and she doesn’t like whisky.

name: John Walker & Sons King George V
nose: Profound smoky initial aroma followed by sweet, fresh fruit (apples, pears, bananas) malt characteristics; developing into rich dried fruit/spicy complexity (raisins, figs, cinnamon).
palate: Smooth with a rich, fruity sweetness. Warming with subtle flavours of sandalwood and smoke.
finish: Mouthwarming and lingering rich peaty finish.
reviews: Bought this for my dad's 80th birthday. He's been a scotch drinker his adult life. He's tasted some fine scotch in his time. He would break out the bottle of Blue on special occasions. When he tasted this, he closed his eyes, grinned, and said "that is the nicest tasting scotch whiskey I've ever had". Me too. || Wow! || The best you can try || Taste of heaven || Johnny Walker has only the best. Plus King George was my 2nd Great Grandfather so to have a bottle named after my ancestor is a treat indeed. Thank you for remembering my family.
_text_all: vanilla toffee honey salt powder oak profound smoky initial aroma followed by sweet fresh fruit apples pears bananas malt characteristics developing into rich dried fruit spicy complexity raisins figs cinnamon smooth with rich fruity sweetness warming with subtle flavours of sandalwood and smoke mouthwarming and lingering rich peaty finish bought this for my dad th birthday he been scotch drinker his adult life he tasted some fine scotch in his time he would break out the bottle of blue on special occasions when he tasted this he closed his eyes grinned and said that is the nicest tasting scotch whisky ve ever had me too wow the best you can try taste of heaven johnny walker has only the best plus king george was my nd great grandfather so to have bottle named after my ancestor is treat indeed thank you for remembering my family

name: Famous Grouse
reviews: This is my go to whiskey, lovely peaty smell,well balanced,with a hint of smoke,most enjoyable tasting blend,would recommend to any whiskey lover, || Grainy, young and sweet blended scotch . Like to know which distilleries supply the chain to blend this saturated whisky demand. Enjoy as a mixer/ cocktail . As neat OK for the price of £16. || Simply a classic. The proletariat everyday blended Scotch that's kept me warm many a winter night. || The only whisky I will have.. After the evening meal and end of the day what better that a famous grouse || In my opinion one of the best low price blends around. It's balanced offering a bit of everything, in nose the candy fruit and the vanilla are predominant over a wood basis and a smoke hint, in mouth is sweet, more caramel than vanilla, the oak improved its presence and in the end you can actually note the sherry cask which is a superb plus at this price. A good and economic choice to share with friends or for a crowded party instead the usual blends.

name: Isle of Skye 8 Year Old Blended Whisky
nose: Stunningly evocative. Deep peaty tones waft from the glass, like the reek from a crofter’s lum. But there is a lot more beyond: the grains intermingle deliciously with oaky, vanilla notes and something malty and even slightly honeyed. The stuff of dreams.
palate: Sweet at first, and remarkably viscous. This seems to be the peat hanging around and there is intense barley sugar and spice.
reviews: This is a lot like a swift-finishing and watered down Speyside. It's very delicate and doesn't offend like a lot of cheap blends do. Pretty nice nose actually. It actually seems pretty malt heavy. The finish and watery tones to this leave a lot to be desired, though. One of the quickest finishes I've had this year. It is still phenominal for a blend and drinks like a cheap single malt.

reviews: I'm not ashamed in the slightest (okay maybe a little, I do call this my 'taterbait' whisky) to say that I bought this whisky for the box. The box is really something else, an impressive wooden construction that looks fantastic on my shelf. Thankfully, there is a surprisingly decent whisky with a rather complex nose and finish. It has a super silky mouthfeel that ultimately makes this very easy to drink. Considering there almost certainly 30-year old Talisker in here, it is rather hidden. The palate comes across grain heavy with more similarities to bourbon than not. While you certainly could do better from a value standpoint, this probably would make a killer gift for someone - especially given the presentation.

name: Black Bottle
nose: Fresh and floral with freshly sawn oak aromas. Spicy with hints of smoke.
palate: Silky, mellow and fruity with balanced smoky / peaty flavours then sweet oak and heather honey.
finish: Soft, elegantly spicy, nutmeg, pepper and a gentle lingering smokiness.
reviews: Nose: Very pleasant nose for me, Oaky, mildly spiced fruit, caramel, floral. Taste: Woody spices, quite thin in viscosity, watery even, mellow. Once swallowed, the next taste, is hard to distinguish, as the finish covers the flavours in the mouth, tastes like it's been watered down, as it's so thin and smooth, it’s the sort of whisky that you could drink alot of and get very drunk, quite quickly as it's so mild. Finish: Not a strong finish, not aggressive like some other Whisky's, it's milder and more refined, a good whisky for evening drinking, it already tastes like it's been diluted with water or ice. Hints of Pepper and a gentle lingering smokiness, perfect for the table, prehaps with cheese to clean your palette before the next course, would I buy again, yes to share amongst dinner guests who are unsure about Whisky's. Perfect with a strong cheese. || Fantastic whisky gentle flavours. Am not a whisky drinker but really love this one || Great for the price. Sometimes you just want a shot of something and not think about it too much. However, that doesn’t mean you should compromise on the flavour. Black Bottle or Double Black by JW and you’ll be grand. || Not impressed || Always buy my Black Bottle from TWE. When I discovered this whisky I found what is now my firm favourite. I’ve heard people say it doesn’t compare well to the original. Well, I never tasted the original so am unable to compare, I love this whisky, a really strong flavour and bite with a m smooth hint of smokiness and a nice (but not too much) sweet rich finish. If you like rich but not overly smokey whisky give this one a go, I’m glad I did!!

name: Whyte & Mackay 21 Year OldBot.1980s
reviews: Sour plum, alluring Chinese Shao Xin. Interesting aroma that evolves as it breathes. Soft but so well texturized. Creamy, yet herbs at the same time. Complex and rounded. Warm scones, baked cherries.Velvety, touch of oldies scent of the oak, gentle sherry sweetness, quinine, colaMedium, finished gracefully, and be mesmerized with the chews of the fine sherry sweetnessSurprisingly good. Fine old cask.
_text_all: no description no description no description no description sour plum alluring chinese shao xin interesting aroma that evolves as it breathes soft but so well texturized creamy yet herbs at the same time complex and rounded warm scones baked cherries velvety touch of oldies scent of the oak gentle sherry sweetness quinine colamedium finished gracefully and be mesmerized with the chews of the fine sherry sweetnesssurprisingly good fine old cask

name: Pure Scot Signature 106
characters: Oak, Vanilla, Apple, Orange, Ginger, Toffee
reviews: Absolutely delicious, by far my favourite whisky so far and I have tried a few. I am a firm fan of the more gentle whiskies, Dalwhinnie instantly springs to mind. But this is instantly smoother which is really dangerous because at 53% ABV it really packs a punch. Flavours of hot buttered toast and Oxford marmalade instantly spring to the fore followed by a light fermented hay flavour and finishes sweet with a honey taste. A blended whisky that can beat many a pure malt into submission? Bladnoch are doing something right!
_text_all: oak vanilla apple orange ginger toffee no description no description no description absolutely delicious by far my favourite whisky so far and have tried few am firm fan of the more gentle whiskies dalwhinnie instantly springs to mind but this is instantly smoother which is really dangerous because at abv it really packs punch flavours of hot buttered toast and oxford marmalade instantly spring to the fore followed by light fermented hay flavour and finishes sweet with honey taste blended whisky that can beat many pure malt into submission bladnoch are doing something right

name: Woven Whisky Experience N.2
characters: White Pepper, Dried Fruit, Lemon, Orange
reviews: Was very excited to try this (and ordered concurrently with Woven #5 - I was that keen to try them). Maybe my expectations were unreasonably high but neither I nor my drinking partner liked either of the two I bought. Fundamentally they just taste like very young whisky; and I thought #2 in particular was very "fresh", and not in a good way unfortunately! I agree with the Woven that blended whisky is very underrated these days due to the single-malt mafia; however, neither of the two products I ordered are going to do blended whisky any favours in my opinion in this regard. I guess they are definitely an "experience", but if you want a nice tasting blended whisky for your nightcap or night out then look elsewhere.
_text_all: white pepper dried fruit lemon orange no description no description no description was very excited to try this and ordered concurrently with woven - was that keen to try them maybe my expectations were unreasonably high but neither nor my drinking partner liked either of the two bought fundamentally they just taste like very young whisky and thought in particular was very fresh and not in good way unfortunately agree with the woven that blended whisky is very underrated these days due to the single-malt mafia however neither of the two products ordered are going to do blended whisky any favours in my opinion in this regard guess they are definitely an experience but if you want nice tasting blended whisky for your nightcap or night out then look elsewhere

name: Johnnie Walker Blue Label Ghost and RarePittyvaich
characters: Ginger, Apple, Blackberry, Vanilla, Cinnamon, Raspberry
reviews: Got as a Xmas present amazing taste a lovely smooth whisky to enjoy on special occasions || I bought this as a gift to give to my husband for completing his US Army basic and AIT training, as J.W. is his favorite spirit. We have not tried it yet (waiting for him to come home), but I can already tell this is a superior scotch. The packaging is beautiful, with a vibrant, elegant graphic on the box, and the color of the bottle is a deep blue hue with a clear center revealing the color of the blended whiskey. We both can't wait to try it when he comes home!

name: Dunhill Old Master
reviews: I have the last few drams of a Dunhill Old Master Finest Scotch Whisky that I'm enjoying tonight R 25615 that was given to by some very old friends in Canada some 40 or so years ago.  When was it bottled and its definitely not for sale as shortly only the bottle will remain, but if I did have a full bottle what would be it worth now as the last bit of it goes down.  Won't make it any better but could make me apreciate a tad more for old times sake. An immediate answer would be great.

name: Royal HouseholdBot.1980s
reviews: I was never a whisky fan until one day at dinner someone took out a bottle of royal household and started pouring for me, it was absolutely stunning and smooth and I polished half a bottle through that dinner. i have been trying to get hold of a bottle for a while now but its not in sight in Singapore || Yes. I love this whisky for its story. 45 years ago I bought a bottle in Rodel on the Isle of Lewis I was told it was the only place in the world you could buy this whisky as it was only made for the Queens households. This may have changed I have my bottle to my father in law who was a brigadier in the Indian Army and an avid whisky collector
_text_all: no description no description no description no description was never whisky fan until one day at dinner someone took out bottle of royal household and started pouring for me it was absolutely stunning and smooth and polished half bottle through that dinner have been trying to get hold of bottle for while now but its not in sight in singapore yes love this whisky for its story years ago bought bottle in rodel on the isle of lewis was told it was the only place in the world you could buy this whisky as it was only made for the queens households this may have changed have my bottle to my father in law who was brigadier in the indian army and an avid whisky collector

name: Dewar's 15 Year OldClock Tin
reviews:
I bought a bottle of this today, mainly because I could not find JW Green, which I sampled last week and enjoyed very much. I tend to like Dewar's' house style; soft and sweet but unafraid to allow the grain to show itself. This expression is...uncomplicated. I've seen reviews claiming to taste all sorts of things in this whisky and I think it is fanciful nonsense. No, there isn't "roasted bananas with a hint of French lilac blossom."
I am a tiny bit disappointed due to one aspect of this dram; the finish is far too short. 
All in all, I think Dewar's should have done a bit better. 
3.5 stars.
_text_all: no description no description no description no description bought bottle of this today mainly because could not find jw green which sampled last week and enjoyed very much tend to like dewar house style soft and sweet but unafraid to allow the grain to show itself this expression is uncomplicated ve seen reviews claiming to taste all sorts of things in this whisky and think it is fanciful nonsense no there isn roasted bananas with hint of french lilac blossom am tiny bit disappointed due to one aspect of this dram the finish is far too short all in all think dewar should have done bit better stars

name: Caledonian 'The Cally' 197440 Year Old Special Releases
nose: Freshly varnished wood, model glue and polish – classic old grain whisky character. Behind those lighter notes sits a mature dram: salted caramel and vanilla toffee spiced up with freshly cracked black pepper.
palate: Rich and thick toffee, more sea salt, and baked apples studded with raisins. As it develops in the glass, concentrated fruity flavours start to come to the front – orange squash (with real fruit) and unsweetened blackcurrant juice.
finish: Lots of spice – liquorice root and cinnamon – fading through nutmeg to a gently tannic and pleasantly sour end.
reviews: Fantastic. Very smooth with great levels. Definitely a sipping Whisky. No water or ice for this one. || Outstanding single grain!
_text_all: honey toffee toast pineapple lime rabbit ravioli scallops freshly varnished wood model glue and polish classic old grain whisky character behind those lighter notes sits mature dram salted caramel and vanilla toffee spiced up with freshly cracked black pepper rich and thick toffee more sea salt and baked apples studded with raisins as it develops in the glass concentrated fruity flavours start to come to the front orange squash with real fruit and unsweetened blackcurrant juice lots of spice liquorice root and cinnamon fading through nutmeg to gently tannic and pleasantly sour end fantastic very smooth with great levels definitely sipping whisky no water or ice for this one outstanding single grain

name: Blanton's Original
main_info: single barrel kentucky straight bourbon whiskey
reviews: Last year, I walked from Ohio over the bridge that straddles the Ohio River into Kentucky just to get a bourbon and Blanton's did not disappoint. I now had the opportunity to relive that experience by buying a bottle of here and wow, I was back there again......just the best bourbon I've ever tasted. || The most wonderful bourbon. So smooth. Wonderful taste. First bought for me in America. Not easy to get. Now I’m buying it for myself over here and it’s not cheap but worth every penny. Just bought another one as a special gift for a friend. || Ignoring the connections to John Wick, this is Bourbon Whiskey is the best I have ever tasted. Mine was dumped on20/03/23 from barrel No 264. Individually selected, filtered and bottled by hand at 93 proof. End result is a bourbon with extra flavour, and an incredible bouquet. It is so smooth then warming and a wonderful after taste. This is the best, well it has to be if John Wick drinks it ;-) || It's the best bourbon I have ever drunk. And it's the best from Blanton family which suits my taste. Really worth it gor a special occasion. || So its Blanton's, 'John Wick Monies', and you will need a Gold Coin to buy one lol :D but you're probably asking me right now, just tell me is it worth the hype, well no and yes (sigh), its a citrus bomb bourbon and complex just as much in its aromas as it is in taste, you really need to have an open mind and like more fruit/spice forward flavours if you want to enjoy this sipper, the vanilla and caramel is there but if you want a simple find that just resembles those of toffee and sugar notes i would go with Makers Mark 46 or better yet Woodford Reserve Double Oak, sometimes simple is better, but hey its also about mood too, you know what im talking about here ;) i payed £80 for this, i wouldn't pay anymore than that, is it worth it? yes i think so for its complexity! Enjoy your Bourbon ?

name: Elijah Craig Small Batch
characters: Caramel, Fruit Cake, Honey, Marmalade, Stewed Fruit
nose: Delightfully complex with notes of vanilla bean, sweet fruit, and fresh mint.
palate: Smooth and warm; pleasantly woody with accents of spice, smoke, and nutmeg
reviews: I love the flavour, with those notes of nuts, caramel and vanilla. || This truly is delicious. I am a huge fan of peated whisky. Smokehead high voltage being my favourite. I can't drink JD. It's just too sweet, but this as a bourbon isn't so sweet. It's a rich dark sweetness something similar to what you would find with Pussers gunpowder proof rum, only more refined. Very smooth. || This is in my sweet spot of proof (between 90-100) for a daily sipper. It has some lovely sweetness without being cloying. There's some oak, spice and vanilla all rolled into one. A good mid-range bourbon that has a lot of those traditional bourbon notes. || Sweet nuts and fruits with pleasant taste. Value for money. Its price in Thessaloniki is 37 euros. || I normally like my whiskey without an e. I got a bottle of this as mainly to make some cocktails. Obviously I have sampled neat it for QC purposes. It’s quite sweet, lots of caramel, rich and almost unctuous reminds me of an xo zacapa rum. The wood, nuts and leather comes out over ice or with water. Works well in a Dry Manhattan or old fashioned.

name: Rittenhouse Bottled In Bond Straight Rye100 Proof
characters: Orange, White Pepper, Honey, Oak, Cinnamon, Tobacco
reviews: Wonderful drink. Really like the spice and warmth. || Strong Full bodied Rye ( this is my first Rye). Not a smooth as Irish Whiskey but it has it's own charm. It will lend itself to mixers because of its dominant flavours. || Purchased for my husband for use in his authentic Manhattan cocktails. He says it is very very good. || STILL DELICIOUS. Reviews below back to 2011 rave and it is still fantastic and affordable. Let it sit for 15 minutes and add a few drops of water. Crazy good. Every sip is a little different. Carmel, rye bread, spice, tobacco, leather and grandpa's old pipe. I think I like this more than my favorite bourbon.

name: Michter's US*1 Small Batch Bourbon
characters: Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Oak, Vanilla, Toffee
nose: Appealingly rich notes of barley sugar, raisins and dried fruit, with a balancing touch of fennel seed and baked bread.
palate: Rich and spicy, with juicy fruit, cinnamon and clean, well-defined flavours.
finish: Welcoming kick of black pepper, then the dried fruit stays strong.
reviews: Wonderful rich fragrance and flavour, with those elements of cinnamon and vanilla. I enjoyed it very much. || A rich and beautifully balanced bourbon. Some cinnamon spice but also a vanilla smoothness at times. No harshness or "burn" and thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish. || Its fantastic. Plain and simple! || Yet another fine offering from Michters. Carmel and vanilla up front with solid oak on the finish. It is well above the competiton in my opinion. || Excellent bourbon, better value than Blanton’s and just as enjoyable.
_text_all: dried fruit cinnamon oak vanilla toffee appealingly rich notes of barley sugar raisins and dried fruit with balancing touch of fennel seed and baked bread rich and spicy with juicy fruit cinnamon and clean well-defined flavours welcoming kick of black pepper then the dried fruit stays strong wonderful rich fragrance and flavour with those elements of cinnamon and vanilla enjoyed it very much rich and beautifully balanced bourbon some cinnamon spice but also vanilla smoothness at times no harshness or burn and thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish its fantastic plain and simple yet another fine offering from michters carmel and vanilla up front with solid oak on the finish it is well above the competiton in my opinion excellent bourbon better value than blanton and just as enjoyable

name: Four Roses Single Barrel Bourbon
main_info: single barrel kentucky straight bourbon whiskey
nose: Fruity, spicy, floral, caramel, vanilla, cocoa, maple syrup, moderately woody.
palate: Hints of ripe plum & cherries, robust, full body, mellow.
reviews: Fantastic bourbon! Bold and intense with fruit and a little bite. Provides a full pallet of flavors. Worth every penny! || I've wanted to try it for sometime, bought a bottle and it exceeded all expectations and now will be a regular bottle amongst the others. || After ayear or so trying out various scotch whiskys I have to admit that this is a refreshing change of direction. Bold, prominent and unique. Very enjoyable. || Tried this one at the Whisky Show. Best bourbon I've ever had. Slight oiliness to the texture and a nice spicy taste. Liquid silk in a bottle, loved it. Would highly recommend. || This is absolutely sensational. Small batch is also incredibly good but single barrel is an absolute gem. Bursting with rich character and super smooth despite it’s proof.

name: Four Roses Small Batch Bourbon
nose: Spicy, rich, mellow, fruity, hints of sweet oak and caramel.
palate: Creamy, mellow, ripened red berries, rich, spicy, well-balanced, moderately sweet.
reviews: beautiful whisky || Best at under 30 USDs in Indiana USA || Really good bourbon || Nice bourbon, has more of a sweetness to it in the bourbon flavour profile. I'm assuming its a lower Rye mix as its not spicy. Really easy drinking I'm not sure its worth the 10 quid extra compared to a buillet or even buffalo trace. || Am I in any way shape or form an expert = no. Do I in all shapes and forms like a good tasting drink = yes. This is a bourbon which benefits from time left in the glass. At sipping it soon after pouring out of the glass, it was harsh and sweet. However, on returning some 8-10mins later the taste was very smooth, sweet and spicy. All thoughts of having to find a chaser for it simply slipped away. A lovely bourbon at a lovely price to make it a regular on my list of favourites - pour, rest, drink and enjoy!

name: Woodford Reserve Distiller's Select
characters: Cinnamon, Brioche, Honey, Mint, Apricot, Sultana
nose: Heavy with rich dried fruit, hints of mint and oranges covered with a dusting of cocoa. Faint vanilla and tobacco spice.
palate: Great balance between sweet fruit, toasty oak and warm spices. Juicy sultanas, cinnamon-dusted pastries and Demerara sugar, freshened up with mint and caraway seed. Deliciously soft mouthfeel.
finish: Silky smooth, almost creamy at first with a long, warm satisfying tail.
reviews:
This is the second time that I drank Woodford Reserve (1.0L). I read all these reviews and that is why I gave it a second shot. Yes, it has a lot of taste, but as with any bourbon, contrary to good single malt whiskies, it always burns my mouth and tongue. Too much. Too too much. This burning sensation destroys every good element. No more bourbons for me || First bourbon trial for me. Had sifferent whiskies and cognacs. This feels like something between a whisky and a cognac (perhaps due to some sweetness but its nicely controlled). Love it. Good value for the money and I rather have this than any vsop cognac. After couple of sips your mouth is full of flavours that stay for long. Brilliant. || There is only one cocktail for me, the Whiskey Old Fashioned.
There is only one bourbon for it, Woodford Reserve. 
I’ve tried them all, Wild Turkey, Beam, Bulleitt, Four Roses, Tin Cup, you name it. 
And although there’s some 8/10, some 9/10, there’s only one 10/10! Woodford. || It's a good balance & affordable  Kentucky Straight Whiskey. || The spiciness surprised me, but it has a very full, very good flavor. Excellent value at its price point.
_text_all: cinnamon brioche honey mint apricot sultana heavy with rich dried fruit hints of mint and oranges covered with dusting of cocoa faint vanilla and tobacco spice great balance between sweet fruit toasty oak and warm spices juicy sultanas cinnamon-dusted pastries and demerara sugar freshened up with mint and caraway seed deliciously soft mouthfeel silky smooth almost creamy at first with long warm satisfying tail this is the second time that drank woodford reserve read all these reviews and that is why gave it second shot yes it has lot of taste but as with any bourbon contrary to good single malt whiskies it always burns my mouth and tongue too much too too much this burning sensation destroys every good element no more bourbons for me first bourbon trial for me had sifferent whiskies and cognacs this feels like something between whisky and cognac perhaps due to some sweetness but its nicely controlled love it good value for the money and rather have this than any vsop cognac after couple of sips your mouth is full of flavours that stay for long brilliant there is only one cocktail for me the whisky old fashioned there is only one bourbon for it woodford reserve ve tried them all wild turkey beam bulleitt four roses tin cup you name it and although there some some there only one woodford it good balance affordable kentucky straight whisky the spiciness surprised me but it has very full very good flavor excellent value at its price point

name: Wild Turkey Longbranch
characters: Butter, Vanilla, Lemon, Caramel, Toffee, Nutmeg
reviews: Nice rich oaky taste - nice to have something different || Honestly didn’t love it, a bit rough around the edges and was missing personality. It goes well with coke though. I would go with bulleit bourbon or buffalo trace as they are in the same price category and are much more smooth, tasty and enjoyable… || Balanced, smooth with a soft gobble-gobble in the background. Fantastic value. || A sweet and really accessible bourbon. Goes fantastic over ice or with a coke. I love wild turkey and my go to is always a buffalo trace. This one, is a worthy alternative for a change from my usual and my wife also enjoys it as she can drink it with a coke or neat. For me, this is testament to the balance it brings. It has my vote. || I've always been a fan of the Wild Turkey Bourbon flavor profile. This falls in with that but has more complexity, fuller flavor and a stronger finish. Currently my favorite bourbon at any price.

name: FEW Bourbon

name: Woodford Reserve Double Oaked
nose: Rich notes of dark fruit, caramel, sharp honey, chocolate, marzipan and toasted oak.
palate: A full-bodied mix of vanilla, dark caramel, hazelnut, apple, fruit and spices.
finish: Long and creamy with lingering hints of honeyed apple.
reviews: Pleasant on the nose, getting werthers original, fruit pastels (the green ones), oat milk and a touch of fresh cut grass. This is a good addition to my collection and sitting proudly between my Ribena and root beer. || An excellent flavourfull bourbon for those who would love a strong oaky taste. I am a scotch guy but whenever I wanna go to bourbon this one is my first choice along with Wild Turkey Rare breed. || Such an incredible bourbon. Rich and smooth and with a great aroma. The addition of the charring really sets it apart. One to enjoy neat. || My all-time favorite bourbon (all-time being 3 years of bourbon drinking for me). I always keep an open bottle and a backup in reserve, but I stick to store picks. Maybe it's just psychological that they taste better, because they're obviously not single-barrel versions, given the fact that double-oaked is finished in a second barrel. || This is such a nice bourbon. I was a bit sceptical about it before purchasing but decided to bite the bullet and try it and honestly it’s earned a permanent place on my shelf.

name: Jack Daniel's Gentleman Jack
nose: Lighter oak and drier on the nose than Old No.7. Vanilla, brown sugar, maple and apple.
palate: Sweet vanilla, stone fruits and apple.
finish: Subtle oak that develops into a smooth finish of fruit with maple and floral honey.
reviews: At Lynchburg distillery they do the right thing to draw customers who enjoyed JD No.7. In Gentleman Jack the smoothness level is turned up a notch compared to No.7. due to double charcoal mellowing. Is it for the better or for worse? Many people enjoy the extra smoothness which comes with even less impurities. On the other hand, this removes some of the smell and taste qualities given by the production process. There will be many whiskey lovers who will not be ready to fork out extra cash for less taste. I'm in this group. To each their own. || I don't like regular JD but this is very smooth with a sweet palette, honey and marzipan flavours and a citrus finish. Very good. || Gentleman Jack. Not surprising why Jack Daniels are about the most well known whiskey. Nothing harsh very easy to drink. Does not need to be mixed with anything, you can go without ice. It is very good liquid gold. (Y) || Excellent quality gift engraved for our friends anniversary. Will be buying again! ?? || Bought it as a gift. Had bottle engraved. Wonderful presentation. Receiver was over the moon with the gift

name: Maker's Mark
nose: Initial sweetness – caramel, brown sugar – gives way to soft fruity notes and vanilla.
palate: More savoury than the nose suggests, with toasted nuts and cinnamon notes.
finish: Initially light but sweet spice builds over time.
reviews:
A perfect introduction to the world of bourbons. Easy sipping, maple syrup and vanilla notes, this is a must have in every home bar. || It a difficult one makers mark. It's a great bourbon if you give it some time in the glass like a good 10 minutes and like most bourbon room temperature or above. It can be very alcohol forward for a 45 percent bourbon if it's not left but there is a wonderful drink here with some really nice sweet bourbon flavours || Initial scent: mothers nail varnish remover, sweetness detected, however, overpowered by menthol on a winters day. Taste: evaporates off the tongue like half a hive of wasps. God forbid you have a cut on your lip. Lingering taste: oaky sunflowers and gasoline. Aftertaste: dry bread and prolonged acid reflux, gives an overwhelming sense of regret. 

 I can honestly say I would rather drink listerine then chug ice water in Antarctica. 

9/10 || This and Woodford Reserve are the two best reasonably-prices bourbons I've tasted. || My whiskey of choice at the moment.
A great drink to end the day.

name: Jim Beam Single Barrel
reviews: I’ve recently bought two bottles of this & they’re both very different whiskeys the first bottle was very balanced quite dry & full of oak, & brown sugar on the nose, all the typical bourbon notes & quite smooth on the finish typically Jim Beam . The other bottle wow boom !!! On the nose sweet maple pancakes, then on the palate vanilla lots of it, maybe some apple strudel in there, yes apple strudel , it’s rougher on the finish , still very dry if not dryer than the first.. lots of rye some artificial sweetness in there but in quite a good way. I’m really enjoying this bottle as it’s nothing like a shelf bought bourbon. It’s very unique, it’s like a flavour bouncing ball around my palate maybe a little too much for some folks. I’m very reluctant to finish this bottle in case I can’t get another. The bottle label noted are below. First Bottle label JB1003 Second Bottle label JB002 || Beautiful! Jim beam is a very underated bourbon in my opinion

name: Bulleit Bourbon Whiskey
nose: Rich and spicy, with warming notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and clove, and crème brûlée topped with Demerara sugar. Hints of dried apricot, grape and almond, too.
palate: Good spicy kick of rye first up, then softer notes of dried fruit and sweet spice follow. Toasty and nutty, with enough fruitiness to soften out the edges.
finish: Well-balanced mix of sweet spice and warming rye.
reviews: Nice bourbon, maybe a tone too sweet for my taste || Love this bourbon, it hits the spot perfectly and its spices leaves my tastebuds tingling. Far exceeds other brands in the price range. Great over ice and would never add a mixer More than I would usually pay for for a bourbon drunk on a regular basis, but well worth the cost. || Sweet smooth yet spicy is it is a perfect sipping sipping whiskey for any time || A high 8.2 out of 10 || This bourbon doesn't taste like regular bourbons,but has a hint & kick of "whiskey" taste to it. Very enjoyable,will definitely buy again!

name: Wild Turkey 101
characters: Cinnamon, Clove, Nutmeg, Hazelnut, Mint, Toffee
nose: Big! Peppery, spicy, lots of rye and caraway seed, but still fresh, with some toffee sweetness in there, too.
palate: Beautiful concentration, with waves of spicy cinnamon, clove and nutmeg, toasted hazelnuts and a faint, fresh, minty note.
finish: The wide-ranging spiciness lasts for a very long time.
reviews: Love this. Have always been a fan of Maker's Mark, Buffalo Trace and Bulleit, probably in that order, but this is different. Hard-hitting, with a deep rich flavour that really lingers (in a good way). It reminds me of Lakes No 5, an atypical English Whisky - not easy drinking, but a nice challenge, to be savoured and remembered. || Without doubt one of the best bourbon for your cash. I've been trying lots of different bourbons over the years as we all do but this is just lovely. Its only bettered I believe by the Wild Turkey rare breed but thats a whole other animal or should I say bird. || Good corn bourbon for good price. || Lovely Rye bourbon..really nice..not too sweet,eell balanced and yummy. || Had this bought for me as a present, won’t drink anything else anymore

name: Buffalo Trace White Dog Mash 1Half Bottle
reviews: This exceeded my expectations by far. First of all, the opportunity to try distillate before it’s aged is such a great experience. It allows one to gauge what flavors are brought on by cask maturation. Second, and this was the surprise, it tastes great. Perfectly drinkable on it’s own, it’s rich and smooth. Five Stars for the opportunity and experience. If you like Bourbon, this is a must try. || I will agree this very unique to me it has sort of popcorn/yeast taste, i didn't have any burn at all but then again I regularly drink real bourbon, the kick wasn't bad either. All that said not something I would buy again not a traditional taste at all. || This product is outstanding !!! White Dog is "unique" very special and is so different to other whiskeys. It is very smooth and so strong the only negative thing I have to say is avout this product is that it could be very addictive as it is such an amazing product, if you like whiskey then you have not lived until you try white dog it truly is the best whiskey on planet earth !!! I also love the bottle as it looks very much like a prescription bottle that a doctor would give out to patients! || This is an expensive curiosity at best. It has an unpleasantly strong corn flavour, some good grain tastes in the finish, and is full of feints. It would be great to know if this is exactly Buffalo Trace Bourbon, but unaged, or a slightly modified recipe/expression. If it is the former, it is a good (but again, a rather expensive) illustration of the effects of aging and oaking on a spirit. If it is the latter, it is a cynical gimmick. || Brought this out to a works do, as is the custom to bring unusual drinks where i work. Burns like the fires of Hades (but in a good way). Thoroughly recommended (good with mixers too) but bear in mind the half size!

name: Wild Turkey Rye
nose: Big, big spicy aromas of caraway seed and plus a breezy freshness.
palate: Warm and mouthfilling, with a lovely dry, characterful spiciness, with some black pepper and notes of caraway seed, rye and fennel seed, plus some faint toffee sweetness.
reviews: This is an excellent rye. Spicy sipping whiskey. Great on the rocks. Unpretentious. || Update - I have since tried the Hudson Manhattan Rye (very disappointing, especially at the price) and Bulleit Bourbon (@28% rye and a more mellow pepper finish than the Wild Turkey): 1st Bulleit, 2nd Wild Turkey and (a very distant) 3rd Hudson Manhattan. Best Whisky Mac so far? For a shot, 1/2 oz Lidl single malt (blue), 1/2 oz Bulleit bourbon, 1/4 oz Rochester ginger. (Using Teachers / Wild Turkey Rye / Rochester in the same proportions is a pretty good alternative - less mellow, more fiery.) || My first try of rye, prompted by a love of a whisky mac followed by a red rye beer. So this Wild Turkey rye was in effect competing with a Teachers/Rochester ginger wine 50:25. Did the same 50:25 whisky/ginger here: liked the nose with the rye better, but found the finish a little too peppery compared to the creamy finish you get with the Teachers. 3/5 for a whisky mac probably isn't that bad really! || Perhaps a little less smooth than expected, having had various Wild Turkey products over the years, but nevertheless a most enjoyable Rye. I'm having a sip now and reckon it benefits from a little dilution, as compared to neat. || My first go on a Rye, glad I tried it but I don't think Rye is to my taste. I have had a few other WT variations and this is my least favourite, due to me not liking Rye rather than this not being great.
_text_all: cinnamon black pepper vanilla leather big big spicy aromas of caraway seed and plus breezy freshness warm and mouthfilling with lovely dry characterful spiciness with some black pepper and notes of caraway seed rye and fennel seed plus some faint toffee sweetness spicy and peppery this is an excellent rye spicy sipping whisky great on the rocks unpretentious update - have since tried the hudson manhattan rye very disappointing especially at the price and bulleit bourbon rye and more mellow pepper finish than the wild turkey st bulleit nd wild turkey and very distant rd hudson manhattan best whisky mac so far for shot oz lidl single malt blue oz bulleit bourbon oz rochester ginger using teachers wild turkey rye rochester in the same proportions is pretty good alternative - less mellow more fiery my first try of rye prompted by love of whisky mac followed by red rye beer so this wild turkey rye was in effect competing with teachers rochester ginger wine did the same whisky ginger here liked the nose with the rye better but found the finish little too peppery compared to the creamy finish you get with the teachers for whisky mac probably isn that bad really perhaps little less smooth than expected having had various wild turkey products over the years but nevertheless most enjoyable rye having sip now and reckon it benefits from little dilution as compared to neat my first go on rye glad tried it but don think rye is to my taste have had few other wt variations and this is my least favourite due to me not liking rye rather than this not being great

name: Strathisla 200715 Year Old Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling

nose: Victoria sponge cake with raspberry jam, spiced shortbread, sultanas, baked apple, candied orange peel and ripe pear. The vanilla from the sponge becomes light custard and apples become apple pie. Creaminess builds along with banana hints.
palate: A big hit of spice and fruit leads to barley sugar sweetness, orange milk-chocolate and lots of orchard fruit – fresh and cooked very ripe apples and pears. Garibaldi biscuits develop, along with berry fruit: blueberries and blackcurrants.
finish: Spiced custard and shortbread with banana hints.

It's a stunning malt, I'm so pleased I treated myself to a bottle. I agree with all the tasting notes. The only comment I would make, for me, at 60%, I needed to add a small splash of water. It opens up beautifully. || This whiskey is so beautiful it is really a work or art

name: Glentauchers 200913 Year Old Sherry Cask Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Fruit Cake, Dried Fruit, Dark Chocolate, Cinnamon, Apple, Biscuits
nose: Cinder toffee and baked apples with baking spice. The toffee slowly becomes chocolate-covered, with brown sugar and a touch of rye crispbread. Dark fruit and spice notes build – speculaas biscuits, dates, treacle toffee and a touch of black liquorice.
palate: Intense, with dark sugars and lots of spice initially. That calms to reveal fruit-studded bread, dark chocolate and baked apples. Eccles cakes and buttered rum follow: intense, dark and spicy.
reviews: This is a wonderful dram. This is something to enjoy over time at the 64.1% ABV, it is definitely a sipper. It coats your tongue with sweetness and leaves a lasting taste. Add a drop of water to open it up (I added just a couple of drops and let it rest for about 15 minutes). I really enjoy it, I do not have a sophisticated palette as veteran whisky drinker, but this awesome in my opinion.

However, I constantly come back to Balvenie 12 Yr Doublewood. I won’t turn down the 17 or 21 for obvious reasons. name: Cardhu 200811 Year Old Special Releases 2020
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Lemon, Orange, Ginger, Toffee, Custard, Honey
nose: Crunchy green apples and just-ripe white pears. Toffee notes build, with heather honey and crunchy barley sugar not far behind. Green herbal notes develop, with sage and rosemary alongside fresh lemon peel and candied orange.
palate: Toffee leads – Highland Toffee bars with zesty lemon and singed orange. The toffee becomes Crunchie innards with a drizzle of honey, a pinch of ginger, spicy baked apples and a dusting of cocoa.
finish: Burnt toffee and baked apples fade to expose gravelly minerality, custard and spice.
reviews: I am a self confessed Cardhu fan. The opportunity to try this 11 year old (2008) was nicely placed before me by The Exchange. It has greater strength to what I am normally used to, and the taste was excellent for me. So I will steadily enjoy, as I sip along during my future evenings. Thank you for supplying a very enjoyable dram ( in my opinion) As always, it arrived perfectly packaged, in good time. Until the next opportunity to try another Cardhu, many thanks. || Bought for my son as a birthday gift. He’s quite a connoisseur when it comes to whisky and he absolutely loved it! || I was not impressed by this whisky. It could by that my palette has not matured sufficiently to appreciate the taste. I found the nose quite ethanol dominate, and the taste was harsh. I will try again in few months again to see if my palette matured to appreciate the whisky. Fingers crossed for the future. || One of the nicest whisky’s I’ve tasted! Bought for me as a 40th birthday present I wasn’t expecting such a flavour profile from an 11 yo. I will soon be getting another bottle.

name: Glen Grant 200022 Year Old Sherry Finish Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Toffee, Prunes, Fruit Cake, Dark Chocolate, Cinnamon, Blackcurrant
nose: Singed toffee, baked apples and prunes to start. Malt loaf and dates develop, along with a touch of butter, liquorice and damp oak. Concentrated fruitiness continues to build: dried cherries and cranberries with blackcurrants.
palate: Blackcurrants and raising jam kick things off, with brown sugar and cinnamon, dates and buttered malt loaf. The fruit builds, as on the nose, although with added dark chocolate and dried citrus peel: orange and lemon.
finish: Dried oranges, chocolate and cake spice lingers.

name: Glenfarclas 25 Year Old London EditionExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Apple, Brioche, Oak, Fruit Cake, Raisins, Coffee
nose: Meadow flowers and barley sugar sit on top of a pile of sultanas and baked apples. Fragrant wax-polished oak follows, with freshly scraped vanilla pods and a touch of pine sap. Buttered brioche and fruit loaf notes develop along with mixed peel and a hint of cream. Hiding underneath is a bed of Eccles-cake raisins and earthy ground coffee.
palate: Rich and oily, with well-fruited sponge cake leading to salted caramel and old oak tables. Singed, buttered toast and buttery pastry are wrapped around fruity espresso and raisins. Dried apple rings liberally spread with blackcurrant jam and sprinkled with brown sugar sit in the middle. Behind everything is an elegant waxiness and freshly polished pine boards.
finish: Lingering sweet spice, light char, sultanas and a touch of hay and honeysuckle.
reviews: Top Notch Dram. This was actually my First Glenfarclas. It is perfection. For the price for a 25 year old a sure bet. || The taste and the strength well balanced. I would prefer it to have a bit more smoke in it, but that is just my personal preference || Personally, I wasn’t so mad on this. I expected more from the age and strength. A bit weak. || Love the 25 year Scotch! Great nose of fruit and caramel. Smooth but lingering with just a bit of smoke. I have tried several better grade Scotches and I would put this one up against any of them. I wish they were more available but I will seek them out to buy them. || Great taste, unbelievable value for 25 year old.

main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Honey, Toffee, Cinnamon, Heather, Pear, Almond
nose: Clean and fresh, with heather honey, pears, a touch of toffee and a soft floral note.
palate: Bright and fruity, but also rich, with notes of steamed syrup pudding and sponge cake, with a little cinnamon and nutmeg.
finish: Just enough spice to match the fruit. Lovely balance.
reviews:
Splendid! 
Simply that. || It's an all time superb single malt whisky. || One of my favorites || There is no such thing has a bad whisky, just different if made well.
Dalwhinnie is very smooth but when compared to teachers blended scotch whisky , 
teachers has the edge on flavor and price both being a smooth whisky. 
My son bought me Dalwinnie for my birthday 24th December . Which i enjoyed but for the price , teachers would have been just as good if not had the edge. 
I with politeness advise the producers to look at their product and add some thing or use better barrels .  The king is in the all together.  Advice is a gift , if listened too.
HAPPY  NEW YEAR . CHEERS. || One of my favorites for sure!

name: Glenfiddich 21 Year OldGran Reserva Rum Cask Finish
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Rum, Dried Fruit, Dark Chocolate, Apple, Butterscotch, Coffee
nose: Rich with a brown sugar / toffee apple character. Also hints of milky coffee.
palate: Rich, with characteristic nuts and cooked fruit. As with the nose, the rum finish has lent greater weight and a noticeable sweetness. The oak is prominent without dominating the lively spirit. Dessert flavours – chocolate sponge cake, toffee pudding, crème brulée, even a hint of pannacotta.
finish: Medium length, doesn’t outstay its welcome.
reviews: The best scotch I have ever had, and I am not a scotch snob! || Amazing taste, really good for the price. I highly recommend || I bought this for birthday. A real disappointment. Not very nice. I was surprised how poor it was. Luckily I got Macallan rare cask black as well which was amazing. The Glenfiddich was not nice || My husband was delighted with this gift and said it was one of the best Whiskey I had bought him. Packaging was lovely and well worth the money as it definitely was a luxury item. || This is one of my favourite whisky's, it's a beautiful colour with a rich and intense flavour that's smooth and enticing . The after taste is almost sweet and makes you want to take another sip.. A great addition to anyones collection.

name: Macallan 18 Year OldSherry Oak 2023 Release
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: Deep rich colour and heady aroma, drank over ice. Quite strong sherry flavour from the oak cask. Not my favourite, personally I found the Macallan Double Cask 12 year smoother and more enjoyable. || I am not a seasoned whisky drinker. I tried this as it comes and I found it very harsh. It made my mouth and nose tingle, and it was difficult to concentrate on the flavour. || Nice colour and aroma with the Spices in this whisky. Great over ice and not too harsh. The sherry taste comes through and tastes perfect. || This whisky was light mahogany in colour with a sherry aroma, another harsh whiskey both in the mouth and as it goes down, much like the Macallan Double Cask 15 year old with the Macallan Double Cask 12 year still being smoother, for my taste that is, this had to be mixed to soften it as well. Based on this I would not buy again or recommend. || A luscious, creamy, rich and almost thick liqueur-like drink, with hints of ginger, spice, and liquorice.

name: Benromach 10 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Liquorice root, Apple, White Pepper, Malt, Smoke
nose: You know what, this greasiness and this mineral smokiness just cannot not make us think of modern Springbank, which can’t be bad news. I find some smoked tea, touches of truffles, graphite oil, quite some fresh barley (or is that porridge?) and quite some raw wool and grass. Old school for sure!
palate: The liquorice and green apple continue from the nose, joined by a maltiness, smoke and spicy cardamom and white pepper.
finish: Quite long, smoky, with notes of agaves and minerals.
reviews: Excellent if you like the flavour profiles shown. Wouldn't say it was a daily sipper but definitely a special occasion dram, a very well balanced whisky. || A good SM for a great price. Mildly smoky with a strong peppery bite, Finishes with a long liquorice note. Well worth the purchase. || Rather good..very sherry,wisp of smoke and maybe liquorice,so everyone wont like this..but overall rather good..think I actually prefer this to Cask Strength,which I tried in October. || Having had a gift of the Benromach 10 yrs aged 43% it's an absolutely lovely smooth Malt Whisky to have with 'very very' little water. Will definitely buy this product again. || Wow! Tried it in a bar in Pitlochry, brought a bottle home. A fantastic balanced whisky that I’ll buy again and again

name: Cardhu Gold ReserveGame of Thrones House Targaryen
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Clove, Apple, Butter, Honey, Oak, Cinnamon
food_paring: Tart Tatin, Dim Sum, Fried Chicken
nose: The golden amber appearance is reinforced on the nose which delivers soft honeyed aromas with a gentle wisp of toasted oak.
palate: On the palate is opens with baked apple & warming spices like cinnamon and allspice that then quickly evolves into a rich caramel character with hints of clove and red apples.
finish: It has a gentle malty biscuit finish.
reviews: This has been my go to tipple for the past 6 years First tried it while on holiday in zakynthos. Soon found myself buying it when I returned home. A lovely smooth drink that I appreciate as a night cap || Super tasty. Buttery mouth feel and complex sweetness. I was surprised the Targaryen House whisky didn't have more smoke intensity... But I guess that's about right for a Cardhu. I recommend buying a bottle if you can still find one.

name: Glenfiddich 15 Year Old Solera
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Sherry, Oak, Marzipan, Cinnamon, Ginger, Apple
nose: An intriguingly complex aroma. Sweet heather honey and vanilla fudge combined with rich dark fruits.
reviews: No expert but trying to learn, smooth and satisfying. During mine with a little water. || I can say categorically that you cannot rate any whisky without taking into consideration the price. I used to be able to pick this up a couple of years ago for under £40.00. At that price absolutely 5 star. But nowadays I'm not so sure. Many whisky's are superb over £40.00 and Glenfiddich 15 is one of them. However price dictates 4 stars. || A bit less powerful on the nose than what I was expecting, almost underwhelming. A very smooth tasting whisky though, but with enough sweet fruity sherry influence and subtle complexity to keep it interesting. A good day to day sipping whisky, this is similar to the rich oak I had a couple of years ago but I think I preferred that just slightly, it had a bit more going on with the extra complexity from the wood influence. Overall I can’t complain too much, it goes down an absolute treat by the fire with a mince pie :) || Im no whisky tasting expert, but I like to look at the tasting notes and see if I can find them. Im really disappointed with the 15. Its pretty bland in my opinion. Not finding any of the tasting notes. Im not getting much on the nose either. I prefer the 12 year bottle. || A straight up sherried whisky, not bad but nothing great, next.

name: Glenfiddich 23 Year OldGrand Cru
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: Soft lemon and pink lady apple notes sit alongside a heavier creaminess. Marzipan and honey brioche follow. The apple becomes more intense with time, picking up grapes, floral honey and the merest hint of red fruits along the way.
palate: Oily. Sweet, honeyed fruits and a rush of cream, then baked apple tart with extra apple skins and flecks of spice. The sweet nuttiness from the nose is present too.
finish: Dry and short, with notes of hazelnuts, brioche and honeysuckle.
reviews: Very nice whisky. However, nothing notable for the price. There are many better whiskies for much less. || Yes, I tried this product, and it was fantastic || I bought this as a gift and my friend was over the moon happy and excited. He LOVES it. The shipping was great as well. Thank you. || This is a delightful expression from Glenfiddich. Don't let the branding on the bottle throw you - this is a beautifully light and floral, classically Glenfiddich dram that is boosted by the patisserie notes. || The packaging alone is something diffent and a far cry from a bottle in a tube. I was quite impressed with the instant creamy mouth feel with sweet notes but not cloying then onto a crisp dry finish. More than what I would normally spend on a bottle but pleased that on the occasion I did it matched my expectations.

name: Glenfiddich 12 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: Distinctively fresh and fruity with a hint of pear. Beautifully crafted and delicately balanced.
finish: A long smooth and mellow finish.
reviews: Glenfiddich 12 is definitely not flamboyant, excessive or fighting for your attention. For me it's an effortless excellence without a big ego, achieving more with less means. || I have tried this product. It's amazing. || Easy drink, light sweet, fruity and grassy single malt. Worth it if you can get it on offer. || Clean and very sweet || Just had a few glasses tonight. Very nice whiskey but lacks complexity. If you just want something “smooth” with a fruity taste pick up a bottle. I’m not a fan of overly strong or heavy drinks so this is perfect for me but more experienced drinkers may find it too basic.
