name: Mortlach 20 Year OldCowie's Blue Seal
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Clove, Raisins, Apple, Dates, Milk Chocolate, Dried Fruit
nose: Super dense and rich, with touches of floor polish and much more of the waxy, earthy, meaty element seen in the previous examples. This has real elegance and complexity - and little intrigue. There is an added oiliness which you only get from mature whiskies. This in turn moves into varnish, leather oil, wood resins and even a touch of dubbin. The sensation is like being in some ancient, mysterious, library. There are dried fruits, a touch of scented wood, fir trees, cedar, Moroccan leather, slightly foxed books, floor polish, and some ink. It grows in the glass, moving towards chanterelle mushroom/cep mushroom even some of the wax crayon also seen on the 12-year-old. Huge, highly complex and contemplative.
palate: The mature depth seen on the nose comes immediately into focus, but before it goes towards the dark there’s a refreshing lift of aromatic and overripe fruits (quince especially) and a touch of spiciness. It then expands as the fruits dry and the oils start to coat the tongue. The meaty element comes in quickly here, full-on grunt with animalic edges, cured leather and light bitter notes that bring to mid nutshell, espresso crema, damson jam, cacao nibs all balanced with some hedgerow berry fruits meaning that the back palate has a brighter lift than you might expect from something which is so dense and meaty (think of a berry sauce with venison). As it develops so this back palate shows more roasting tin elements, some bark. It continues to extend into dried fruits.
finish: Quite dense. It carries on seamlessly from the progression seen on the palate with liquorice and dried fruit.
reviews: I tried this product at the last whisky show and I liked it. Until I tried the 16 year old, which I liked a lot more. Rather than buying a 20yo, I sooner but 2 bottles of the 16yo and have enough left over for a bottle of Clynelish 24yo. || A great sip, and a lovely mildly sherried Speyside. But, it still can't seem to match the epic style and purity of the original Mortlach bottlings from a decade ago. || We have thoroughly enjoyed our introduction to Mortlach through the 16 year Flora and Fauna series first discovered on a visit to Edinburgh several years ago where it was compared to a Macallan's 25 at the shop, to the Mortlach 16 and on .....to the Mortlach 20. This continues our love for the distillery's products and the taste, smell and palate that is put into each cask and eventually in the bottle. We only wish we could tour the distillery when we visit Scotland late April/early May 2023. || We have thoroughly enjoyed our introduction to Mortlach through the 16 year Flora and Fauna series first discovered on a visit to Edinburgh several years ago where it was compared to a Macallan's 25 at the shop, to the Mortlach 16 and on .....to the Mortlach 20. This continues our love for the distillery's products and the taste, smell and palate that is put into each cask and eventually in the bottle. We only wish we could tour the distillery when we visit Scotland late April/early May 2023.

name: Benrinnes 200912 Year Old Sherry Cask The Whisky Exchange
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
characters: Toffee, Apple, Sultana, Coffee, Hazelnut, Grape
nose: Buttery apple pie and toffee apples to start, all bathed in sticky caramel sauce. Big green apple notes build, dowsed with vanilla cream. Hints of sultana and nectarine develop, along with sweet grapes and a touch of muscovado sugar.
palate: Creamy vanilla toffee and the sharp apples from the nose lead to creamy coffee and baking spice: cinnamon and clove. The toffee continues to build along with touches of hazelnut and crunchy spun sugar.
finish: Hazelnuts and cinnamon spice fade to reveal vanilla toffee and green apple.
reviews: Really wonder full smell, good taste and long pleasant finish. The little smoke from the beginning just for the improvement of the smell taste and finish. My rate above 90. It is good choice for this price, unfortunately limited edition

name: Mortlach 200321 Year Old Bourbon Cask Signatory for TWE
characters: Vanilla, Hazelnut, Almond, Candied peel, Dried Fruit, Pineapple
nose: Salted butter, a little dry cured ham, and fruity notes of crab apple jelly and pineapple. Then candied walnuts, peanuts and hazelnuts.
palate: Shortbread, stewed apples and pears, plum wine, toffee, pineapple cubes, and ginger beer. That spiciness persists with cassia, turmeric, and a prickle of dry oak.
finish: The creamy toffee notes stay on the palate along with bags of roasted nuts and dried stone fruit.
_text_all: vanilla hazelnut almond candied peel dried fruit pineapple salted butter little dry cured ham and fruity notes of crab apple jelly and pineapple then candied walnuts peanuts and hazelnuts shortbread stewed apples and pears plum wine toffee pineapple cubes and ginger beer that spiciness persists with cassia turmeric and prickle of dry oak the creamy toffee notes stay on the palate along with bags of roasted nuts and dried stone fruit

name: Cardhu 18 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Milk Chocolate, Cherry, Coffee, Mint, Pear
nose: Not forward, yet attractively ‘natural’ and in time rich, balanced and very complex. Macerated fruits; pears, plums, cherries. Hints of pineapple develop a light, green, gooseberry-like edge. Delicate scents of wild rose, menthol and polished leather rise above a soft base of Christmas cake or buttery pastry. Water opens it all up elegantly, without altering the main themes.
palate: A smooth and sweet taste, unctuous, yet with light and lively acidity. The soft, delicate, fruity core is cradled by rich, chocolate-edged flavours, the texture, chocolate and fruit combining to evoke a cherry liqueur chocolate truffle. Warming overall, it’s softer with water, when the balance of tastes remains the same, though lighter.
finish: Exciting and complex, the conclusion is long, smooth, gently drying and rich in cocoa.
reviews: Let me start by saying that I am not a whisky expert, but I do enjoy The Cardhu. Found it with the Gold reserve, extended with the 12 year old found in Gibraltar, and most recently the 18 year old. I do enjoy sipping a smooth whisky with a taste that I personally find enjoyable, and this has such a depth, it is excellent. Will be enjoyed in the future. || Really lovely smooth but also rich woody18 year old. Also, a great price for a 18 year old Soeyside of this quality.. Very underrated and great value compared to the big 4 (Macallan, Glenmorangie, Glenlivet and Glenfiddich) ??. || I am so disappointed about this drink, it tasted thin and perfumy. It was nothing compared to the 3cl I bought to try, which was malty, woody, rich and sweet! rip off! || Truly INCREDIBLE! I only wish I could buy it in the USA. I brought two bottles back with me from Scotland. The distillery tour was AWESOME too! || Love the spiciness and finish of this whisky. Lovely everyday whisky!
_text_all: milk chocolate cherry coffee mint pear not forward yet attractively natural and in time rich balanced and very complex macerated fruits pears plums cherries hints of pineapple develop light green gooseberry-like edge delicate scents of wild rose menthol and polished leather rise above soft base of christmas cake or buttery pastry water opens it all up elegantly without altering the main themes smooth and sweet taste unctuous yet with light and lively acidity the soft delicate fruity core is cradled by rich chocolate-edged flavours the texture chocolate and fruit combining to evoke cherry liqueur chocolate truffle warming overall it softer with water when the balance of tastes remains the same though lighter exciting and complex the conclusion is long smooth gently drying and rich in cocoa let me start by saying that am not whisky expert but do enjoy the cardhu found it with the gold reserve extended with the year old found in gibraltar and most recently the year old do enjoy sipping smooth whisky with taste that personally find enjoyable and this has such depth it is excellent will be enjoyed in the future really lovely smooth but also rich woody year old also great price for year old soeyside of this quality very underrated and great value compared to the big macallan glenmorangie glenlivet and glenfiddich am so disappointed about this drink it tasted thin and perfumy it was nothing compared to the cl bought to try which was malty woody rich and sweet rip off truly incredible only wish could buy it in the usa brought two bottles back with me from scotland the distillery tour was awesome too love the spiciness and finish of this whisky lovely everyday whisky

name: Glenfarclas 105°
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Christmas Cake, Liquorice root, Prunes, Dates
nose: Complex, oaky, apples and pears, and a tempting dark toffee sweetness.
finish: Amazingly smooth for the strength; wonderfully warming and with a lingering smokiness, yet very rounded.
reviews: Holy Hell…this is my new fav dram! Such a bang for your hard earned cash! I first tried 105 in The Ben Mhor Hotel Bar in Grantown Upon Spey and have never looked back. It’s got superlative balance with just the right dryness but depth of flavour and wonderful minerality that seeps down deep into your chest. I had some concern that it the alcohol would burn but so so wrong…this is fine whisky at its finest (in my humble view) and scouring is absent replaced instead by a subtle honey sweetness…and I mean subtle, making this very deliciously drinkable. An absolute bucket list dram if ever there was one and I challenge any to disagree without trying it first. I think at least 8-10years aged and don’t let the alcohol content scare you. Bold, but in totally the right way :) || OMG. Strong Strong Strong, but very nice, needs a touch of water to release more of the flavours. Buy Buy Buy || I like strength & strong whisky. || I’ve had about 6 bottles (not all at once) over the years and, buy when I see it. The nose, is eye watering and is very complex in tasting, I take it with a teaspoon or perhaps a bit more water. All I can say is I’ve just bought another bottle the other day and am looking forward to Christmas when I’ll share it for my friends. I also have five more whiskies, mainly from Isla, my first love. || Definitely need some water to feel the different aromas. Is perfect after heavy Christmas lunch and you need to try it.
_text_all: christmas cake liquorice root prunes dates complex oaky apples and pears and tempting dark toffee sweetness no description amazingly smooth for the strength wonderfully warming and with lingering smokiness yet very rounded holy hell this is my new fav dram such bang for your hard earned cash first tried in the ben mhor hotel bar in grantown upon spey and have never looked back it got superlative balance with just the right dryness but depth of flavour and wonderful minerality that seeps down deep into your chest had some concern that it the alcohol would burn but so so wrong this is fine whisky at its finest in my humble view and scouring is absent replaced instead by subtle honey sweetness and mean subtle making this very deliciously drinkable an absolute bucket list dram if ever there was one and challenge any to disagree without trying it first think at least - years aged and don let the alcohol content scare you bold but in totally the right way omg strong strong strong but very nice needs touch of water to release more of the flavours buy buy buy like strength strong whisky ve had about bottles not all at once over the years and buy when see it the nose is eye watering and is very complex in tasting take it with teaspoon or perhaps bit more water all can say is ve just bought another bottle the other day and am looking forward to christmas when ll share it for my friends also have five more whiskies mainly from isla my first love definitely need some water to feel the different aromas is perfect after heavy christmas lunch and you need to try it

name: Linkwood 201310 Year Old The Seasons: Spring
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
characters: Wildflowers, Lemon, Vanilla, Cream, Peardrops, Honeycomb
nose: Pears, greengages, lime leaves, honeysuckle, lemongrass, spearmint, fresh linen sheets, green apple sweets and a Gin Gimlet. The American oak influence is subtle, bringing vanilla custard, peppermint creams and desiccated coconut.
palate: Limoncello, yuzu sake, juicy fruit chewing gum, cloudy apple juice and spearmint. There’s also a floral side, with orange blossoms, lilacs, and elderflowers followed by grass lawns after a rain shower.
finish: Vanilla pods and some good salted butter, then subtly spicy with white pepper, celery seed and fennel pollen.
_text_all: wildflowers lemon vanilla cream peardrops honeycomb pears greengages lime leaves honeysuckle lemongrass spearmint fresh linen sheets green apple sweets and gin gimlet the american oak influence is subtle bringing vanilla custard peppermint creams and desiccated coconut limoncello yuzu sake juicy fruit chewing gum cloudy apple juice and spearmint there also floral side with orange blossoms lilacs and elderflowers followed by grass lawns after rain shower vanilla pods and some good salted butter then subtly spicy with white pepper celery seed and fennel pollen

name: Glenlivet 15 Year OldFrench Oak Reserve
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: Not for me, bit harsh || Nose seems muted, palate is creamy, finish a little peppery. All in all not a bad dram || his is one of the malts I keep going back to, really enjoy the influence of the French oak casks. Color is a deep gold, amber. Nose is fruity, I get raisins and ripening apples, oak is rich. On the palate I can taste dried fruits, cinnamon, but not overpowering. Finish is where I think this one shines (I thinks so anyway). Nice long dry finish, peppery, honey sweetness comes through, a bit more oak, at times some caramel. Leaves a long lasting satisfying flavor despite have a medium body feel. Only wish that ABV was a bit higher. || Not a bad dram, slightly harsh tasting initslly. Floral & toffee notes, wouldn’t personally buy after having the sample. Would rather have The Dalmore 15 which for me is in a different league || This is a wonderfully smooth quality malt whisky at a surprisingly good price for one this good.

name: Benrinnes 15 Year OldFlora & Fauna
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: Pleasant if a little simple. Not overly complex. Having experimented I think it is nicer as a before dinner sharpener. The first few drams were very sweet and little else. The bottle opened up after a while. The flavour reminds me of a common blend, Bells or Teachers or one of those, but with more body and sweetness. I initially thought I would not get any more then I bought a second bottle, one is allowed to change. one's mind! It is smooth, lots of body, sweetish and enjoyable. Makes a pleasant change from chewing a heavy Islay malt. || This is hands down one of the best Scotches I have ever had in my life (and I've had a lot). It's so well-balanced, complex, smooth, sweet....it's as good as it gets! I can't believe the majority of this distillery's Scotch goes to some blended whiskey. Everyone I have shared this with also completely loved it. Giving this Scotch 5 stars does not do it justice.....sooo incredible!! || After the Linkwood of the same range Flora and Fauna , again this is a great dram. It maybe 43%, but clings to you're glass, loads of florals and deep fruits. For the money good buy.

name: Glenfarclas 21 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Vanilla, Liquorice root, Brioche, Cinnamon, Dried Fruit, Apple
nose: Intense, full of aromas – sherried fruit, tropical fruit, nutmeg and almonds with slight citrus notes at the end, all held together with a vanilla sweet smokiness.
palate: Thick and sweet, with less complexity than the nose, zeroing in on brown sugar, stewed orange segments and lightly spiced syrup. A drop of water opened out the body a bit, softening the syrup hit and bringing out more fruit, with apples, apricots and blackcurrant leaves, as well as a bit more crunchy caramel sweetness.
finish: Long-lasting, smooth a smoky with a chocolate feel at the back of your throat.
reviews: This is some amazingly well made whiskey and it tastes incredible. This is my first time experiencing a whiskey aged 21 years. I’ll definitely get more of this and I’m looking forward to trying the 25 year as well! || This is a wonderful dram and actually very good value for money for a 21 year old. It's not one that will please all the sherry cask lovers, but it is beautifully refined and sweet in a different way. A nice smooth easy drinking dram with lots of character. Sweet to the nose. Oak, malt, dried fruit and a hint of chocolate on first taste. As it goes on, the fruit notes come through with hints of dried fruit tastes to the palate. The finish is what makes it worth it. You are left with that sweet satisfying taste that makes you want more... Another outstanding dram from Glenfarclas. Can't wait to try the 25yo. || Extremely smooth, warming and a deep rich flavour. I would highly recommend! || Utterly stunning || Really smooth, barley oaty taste with a hint of citrus & sweetness. I’m new to 21yr olds so not a lot to compare it to but loved it!
_text_all: vanilla liquorice root brioche cinnamon dried fruit apple intense full of aromas sherried fruit tropical fruit nutmeg and almonds with slight citrus notes at the end all held together with vanilla sweet smokiness thick and sweet with less complexity than the nose zeroing in on brown sugar stewed orange segments and lightly spiced syrup drop of water opened out the body bit softening the syrup hit and bringing out more fruit with apples apricots and blackcurrant leaves as well as bit more crunchy caramel sweetness long-lasting smooth smoky with chocolate feel at the back of your throat this is some amazingly well made whisky and it tastes incredible this is my first time experiencing whisky aged years ll definitely get more of this and looking forward to trying the year as well this is wonderful dram and actually very good value for money for year old it not one that will please all the sherry cask lovers but it is beautifully refined and sweet in different way nice smooth easy drinking dram with lots of character sweet to the nose oak malt dried fruit and hint of chocolate on first taste as it goes on the fruit notes come through with hints of dried fruit tastes to the palate the finish is what makes it worth it you are left with that sweet satisfying taste that makes you want more another outstanding dram from glenfarclas can wait to try the yo extremely smooth warming and deep rich flavour would highly recommend utterly stunning really smooth barley oaty taste with hint of citrus sweetness new to yr olds so not lot to compare it to but loved it

name: Aultmore 201111 Year Old The Whisky Exchange
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
characters: Peach, Rhubarb, Vanilla, Clove, Mint, Toffee
nose: Buttery crumble topping with sharp rhubarb and softly sweet peaches are joined by crunchy barley sugar and boiled sweets: apple, pineapple and pear. Savoury brown butter and pastry notes build, balanced by sweet cream and dried apricot. Juicy stone fruit notes develop.
palate: Sweet, buttery pastry and sherbet lemons are balanced by gentle spice. Things continue with fresh and zingy fruit notes – sharp peach and apple – on one side and sweet grain the other – porridge and granola.
finish: Apple pie and buttery pasty with touches of chocolate at first. Aniseed and porridgey grain linger.

name: Craigellachie 13 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: Big tropical-fruit aromas at first – mango and pineapple – followed by sweet and savoury notes of ham glazed with Demerara sugar and a whiff of barbecue smoke.
palate: More sweet fruit, tempered by savoury smokiness. Punchy and full-flavoured, with the meaty smoke balancing well with the refreshing tropical fruit. Mouth-filling texture; makes a statement!.
finish: The smoked-meat notes gently fade, along with a hint of spent match.
reviews: Sherry maturation instantly on the nose with some new shoe leather. An unusually robust, full flavoured dram for a Speyside which sets it apart. Tropical fruits early with the faintest hint of smoke on the finish. Delightful neat or with a drop of water. Waited a long time to have this in my collection. Thank you Maureen. || Love at first taste || Was so disappointed with this.It had been on my hitlist for ages and lo and behold I got a free sample.I know it's not a good premis for an opinion but it has made me pause and reflect.So many more out there to try!2.75/5 || Pour a fat dram, add a drop of water, and just leave it alone for a while. Let the matchstick subside (I love wormtubs!) with a rest in the glass. Enjoy. This whisky is fabulous. || Delicious!

name: Aberlour 12 Year Old Non Chill-Filtered
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Plums, Dark Chocolate, Toffee, Cinnamon, Raisins
nose: Rich and fruity with notes of sweet strawberry jam.
palate: Sherried character and deep fruity plum aromas balanced with rich chocolate, toffee, cinnamon and raisins.
finish: Long, sweet and very slightly spicy.
reviews: An excellent offering from Aberlour. I enjoy malt whisky in a whole range of styles, from smoky Islays to rich "sherry bombs" and all points between. But among the sweeter whiskies Aberlour has long been a firm favourite. While the flavours and aromas here are unmistakably Aberlour, the higher ABV and lack of filtration seem to slightly de-emphasise its inherent sweetness and allow significantly more complexity to show through. And though certainly not a "beginners' malt", the high ABV is very well integrated and never overly aggressive to drink neat (my own preference). All in all, while the core 12yo expression remains a favourite "easy-drinker", this is a whisky that thoroughly rewards more time and attention to savouring and is a real star turn in "bang for buck". This seems to no longer be available, and I REALLY hope that is only a temporary situation, as this is a whisky I would love to buy regularly in future as I'm sure others will too. || A tragically ignored gem of a whisky. Milk chocolate covered raisins, plums, toffee, sweet strawberries, spices and some dark chocolate oak to balance it out. All the other Aberlour expressions (except A'bunadh) are bottled at a paltry 40-43% ABV and I'm always left thinking how wonderful it would be if they had more presence, more power. With this dram I was not disappointed. Highly recommended! || Exceptional sherried whisky, more refined than the A’bunadh in my opinion and only surpassed by the magical Macallan Cask Strength || Very good,tasty dram this at a good 48%,so strong and full of flavour...well worth the reasonable price for the high quality you get!?? || Nice dram this one with caramel and vanilla..possibly hints of cinnamon.Good value for money..
_text_all: plums dark chocolate toffee cinnamon raisins rich and fruity with notes of sweet strawberry jam sherried character and deep fruity plum aromas balanced with rich chocolate toffee cinnamon and raisins long sweet and very slightly spicy an excellent offering from aberlour enjoy malt whisky in whole range of styles from smoky islays to rich sherry bombs and all points between but among the sweeter whiskies aberlour has long been firm favourite while the flavours and aromas here are unmistakably aberlour the higher abv and lack of filtration seem to slightly de-emphasise its inherent sweetness and allow significantly more complexity to show through and though certainly not beginners malt the high abv is very well integrated and never overly aggressive to drink neat my own preference all in all while the core yo expression remains favourite easy-drinker this is whisky that thoroughly rewards more time and attention to savouring and is real star turn in bang for buck this seems to no longer be available and really hope that is only temporary situation as this is whisky would love to buy regularly in future as sure others will too tragically ignored gem of whisky milk chocolate covered raisins plums toffee sweet strawberries spices and some dark chocolate oak to balance it out all the other aberlour expressions except bunadh are bottled at paltry - abv and always left thinking how wonderful it would be if they had more presence more power with this dram was not disappointed highly recommended exceptional sherried whisky more refined than the bunadh in my opinion and only surpassed by the magical macallan cask strength very good tasty dram this at good so strong and full of flavour well worth the reasonable price for the high quality you get nice dram this one with caramel and vanilla possibly hints of cinnamon good value for money

name: Glenlivet 12 Year Old Double Oak

reviews: Maybe it's my palate but I got a bitter or Bland flavor. No sweetness to be had. Brand new bottle, poured a bit over a cube of ice and a TINY splash of water. The warmth wasn't bad even nice feeling it travel all the way to my stomach and it was admittedly very smooth. I'm just not getting the flavors, notes etc that are described. || I'm more of an Irish Whiskey drinker but this is my go-to for Scotch Whisky...not too smokey. || Very smooth Scotch. Nice blended smoky flavour mixed with an essence of fruity notes. || It’s my absolute favorite drink, second to none. Great flavor, smooth and satisfying. || Scotch for beginner's, but it's a good entry into the scotch. Speyside whisky are usually are sweet and some have an floral testing with them.

name: Glen Moray 1998Barolo Finish Warehouse 1 Release

reviews: I've just finished my first bottle of this stunning dram & luckily have another bottle left to enjoy. There's numerous flavours hitting your taste buds time and time again. It's a whisky to explore & savor, as those flavours come in waves & leave a satisfying finish. Even smelling the empty bottle is a pleasure in itself ! I think the price is par for the course at around £138 for a 23yr old bottled at 52.9% abv, non chill filtered, natural colour & only 853 bottles in total (what do folk expect). Buy & enjoy.......slowly || It’s ok, I get all the flavours as described. Definitely caramel chocolates. It’s a very ‘spiky’ though and for the price I would have preferred a much more ‘rounded’ effort. Yes the abv is up there but I was left feeling a little disappointed. At a cheaper price point I would have not felt that as it’s not a bad whisky and I did enjoy the barolo finish. || Nice, but fairly unremarkable and not worth the price in my opinion.

name: Mortlach 16 Year OldDistiller's Dram
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Raisins, Apple, Clove, Dark Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Dates
nose: Rich and deep. It is slightly shy initially, but with a sense of massed weight. Stewed black and orchard fruits (damson, black cherry) with an immediate earthy note and some spice. While there is some honeyed sweetness, this has greater maturity than the 12-year-old, coming across as leaf mulch, with a burnt element: dried Nora pepper/grilled red pepper and light blackened skin (the pepper’s that is, not human) and chocolate which moves the meatiness towards molé. The oak is more relaxed (or integrated) allowing the gutsy almost feral weight of the distillate greater say but there is some planed wood alongside light varnish, then nutmeg and raisin. It gets progressively darker and richer with some biltong/beef jerky hints balanced by the sweetness. It also gets slightly nuttier, reminiscent of mature Gouda/Emmental.
palate: Big, quite deep, but also sweet. As on the nose, there’s some spiciness here (frying mustard seed). It is this sweeter element (toffee-like, with some dried apricot and the honey note seen on the nose) which comes over first. This softness then gives way to a chewy-mid palate where the darker fruits lurk. It then goes deep. Light, slightly leathery with malty elements then a gamey meatiness with supple tannins. However, rather than just the more powerful oak influence beginning to dominate the cooked fruits return adding a layered quality. Rather than sweetness you get a more savoury effect. Dark, full, liquorous, and rounded. As it moves into the back palate, so it starts to dry and pick up in terms of intensity and moves into the shadow of the trees.
finish: Surprisingly, it sweetens again. Long, complex and, yes, meaty. Now you also get the Syrah-like sootiness.
reviews:
I had purchased a couple of bottles of the 16-year-old Mortlach about12 years ago and I found it to be exceptional. That was the flora & fauna release. || Sherry, toffee, herbaceous on the nose. Caramel, salty, savoury, sticking plasters, straw, sour, lot’s going on. Bit full on alcohol hit but not burning. Finish is smooth and complex but overall savoury for me. || I just love it ! || Exceptional and exquisite whiskey.
Remain in your palate for long with different tastes and flavour 
Highly recommended || I've had this before,  its a damn good whisky, full flavoured and as they say...it is the beast of Dufftown.
I would prefer if it were non chill filtered and no caramel, just to see if it tastes any better but apart from that, i love my Mortlachs and always have.

damson black cherry with an immediate earthy note and some spice while there is some honeyed sweetness this has greater maturity than the -year-old coming across as leaf mulch with burnt element dried nora pepper grilled red pepper and light blackened skin the pepper that is not human and chocolate which moves the meatiness towards mol the oak is more relaxed or integrated allowing the gutsy almost feral weight of the distillate greater say but there is some planed wood alongside light varnish then nutmeg and raisin it gets progressively darker and richer with some biltong beef jerky hints balanced by the sweetness it also gets slightly nuttier reminiscent of mature gouda emmental big quite deep but also sweet as on the nose there some spiciness here frying mustard seed it is this sweeter element toffee-like with some dried apricot and the honey note seen on the nose which comes over first this softness then gives way to chewy-mid palate where the darker fruits lurk it then goes deep light slightly leathery with malty elements then gamey meatiness with supple tannins however rather than just the more powerful oak influence beginning to dominate the cooked fruits return adding layered quality rather than sweetness you get more savoury effect dark full liquorous and rounded as it moves into the back palate so it starts to dry and pick up in terms of intensity and moves into the shadow of the trees surprisingly it sweetens again long complex and yes meaty now you also get the syrah-like sootiness had purchased couple of bottles of the -year-old mortlach about years ago and found it to be exceptional that was the flora fauna release sherry toffee herbaceous on the nose caramel salty savoury sticking plasters straw sour lot going on bit full on alcohol hit but not burning finish is smooth and complex but overall savoury for me just love it exceptional and exquisite whisky remain in your palate for long with different tastes and flavour highly recommended ve had this before its damn good whisky full flavoured and as they say it is the beast of dufftown would prefer if it were non chill filtered and no caramel just to see if it tastes any name: Glenfiddich Project XXExperimental Series
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Apple, Orange, Hazelnut, Biscuits
nose: Barley sugar and lardy cake are followed by dry cinnamon and nutmeg notes. Then things get juicy, with pine needles, freshly peeled orange zest, lime jelly and hints of Haribo. Water adds in layers of fruity toffee.
palate: Chocolate-covered caramels, black pepper, orange cream and singed orange peel lead things, with milk-chocolate truffles and hazelnuts bringing up the rear. Water reveals the toffee from the nose on the palate as well as adding sweet stewed apples and sharp Granny Smiths.
finish: Dry and softly spicy to start, with sweet hints of digestive and shortbread biscuits building with butter and spice.
reviews: Some nice plop. Great work chaps || Standard Glenfiddich whiskey. Not the best one nor the worst. Alcohol content to strong. Fire @ Cane more enjoyable || Not my favourite whisky from the Glenfiddich range but pleasant enough. First taste isn’t the best but once you’ve had a few sips it grows on you. || Not a Glenfiddich fan, however the oakiness has been replaced with a sweet spicy backbone which resembles the glendronach 12 mixed with redbreast's lustau. This is one to try for the discerning sweet tooth drinker. At 47% this is incredibly drinkable and has a resemblance to more expensive whiskies such as glenmorangie signet or glenfarclas 105. || Can’t believe that I’m the first to review this phenomenal masterpiece! Smooth and sweet with candy floss, chocolate, etc. , complemented well by nuttiness and orange. It is as good as many 150-200? whiskies I’ve seen. Something you must try!

name: Benromach 15 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Milk Chocolate, Fruit Cake, Ginger, Apple, Mint, Honey
nose: Chocolate, caramel and wood smoke lead to a hint of new-trainer-sole rubber and rich maltiness – Shreddies cereal and malt extract. The smokiness winds its way through the gaps, becoming wispy coal smoke trickling out of a stove filled with baking sultana-studded apples.
palate: Rich, thick and rounded, with sultanas and raisins quickly overwhelmed by spicy peat smoke. The baked apples from the nose are revealed as the smoke blows away, sprinkled with spicy cinnamon and mint leaves. Chocolate-covered liquorice and Hob Nob biscuits appear, along with a touch of charcoal.
finish: Singed fruit cake and sultana-heavy fruit loaf fade slowly away to leave tingling menthol, leafy mint and cocoa.
reviews: Splendid dram, rich fruit,lightly spiced with a hint of smoke.a good winter warmer || Has loads of character. Hint of peat on the nose and strong oak flavours but remains smooth. Has spice and bite. Cereal notes are strong. Quite a dry finish. Good. || Cannot try the product, because it is a X-mas present to some one (who may be able to comment at a later date !). But as I have seen many "old" whiskies it is one of the good products, otherwise it would not have been voted Whisky of the year. || Not my thing. Just did not impress. I had a mouthful of whisky which is about the end of it. || Excellent :)

name: Craigellachie 17 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Dried Fruit, Pineapple, Vanilla, Malt, Oak, Liquorice root
reviews: Well balanced and tasty. A surprise. || This is a surprise and a joy. The Craigellachie spirit is often too sulfury for my tastes, but this is an amazingly balanced, and well-crafted dram. The cask balance is perfect, a mixture of malt and sweet and spice... it is not dominated by any, but luxurious in each. It blows away the 13 year and I only wish my bottle was more full. The nose is a spectrum of fruits with a hint of oak, but on the palate the oak is glorious and mostly manifest as spices from the kitchen... a hint of ginger and curry, peaches and plums, cinnamon toast, a bit of coconut and maple syrup... and a gushing backbone of maltiness. Way too drinkable... || Rarely have I been privileged to try such a stunning, yet balanced dram. Craigellachie is often to sulfury for me, yet this whisky is divine, and balanced so well as to be nearly indecipherable. The heart of the whisky is a perfect balance of sherry and bourbon casks, sweet and spicy, with only a hint of ancient wood. Fruits and winter spices, but sung throughout with strong barley and breakfast breads... more, please. I feel lucky. || Very impressed, very smooth and I enjoy the touch of sweetness. And a tad bit of smoke..very easy to drink , no burn. Very good , if u enjoy Hibiki, or Monkey Shoulder's, this is far superior. || A splendid taste with a warm feel to it. Not to smoky but silky smooth.

name: Caperdonich 200021 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cherry, Almond, Vanilla, Fruit Cake, Pear, Toffee
nose: Cherry Bakewells – vanilla custard, hints of light fruit cake and a touch of orgeat almond. Fruity notes build: apple sauce with sultanas, spice and a touch of banana.
palate: Creamy toffee and caramel leading to spiced apple and fruit cake. The cherry and almond notes from the nose reappear along with singed raisins and custard. Polished oak and lardy cake notes poke out the sides. Fresh apple and roasted pears with a touch of sharp white grape.
finish: Creamy spiced apple and cream notes slowly.
reviews: I really enjoy hibiki masters blend available only from duty free . But this was something else. I am going to purchase another bottle to keep for a few years. The subtle fruit cake and citrus flavours that came through really mixed well with my cigar choice and light chocolate to accompany it. || Seemed almost a bit of smoke or pear . Sweet. Full bodied. Sophisticated. Enjoyable. And a bit different. Orange. Smooth.

main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling

nose: Billowing soft peat notes, like distant smoke on the wind. Rich sweet toffee and zesty fresh fruit notes and spiciness.
palate: Like a Highland peat campfire, with oak notes and toffee. Sharp green fruit, sweet baked apples and soft smoke.
reviews: Itvwas purchased for my 60th birthday. What a delight. Its smooth very tasty and didnt last long in the bottle. For a single malt whisky its way up there. || I was a bit sceptical at first to buy this but boy am I happy I did. This has quickly become my favourite scotch. It's very different and unique. Taste wise it's not something you will find with other scotches. The smokiness comes through more here than anything else I've tried. It's sweet but it isn't overpowering. It goes down smooth and doesn't have much of a bite. If you don't like smoky then this isn't a scotch for you but that balance between sweet and smoky makes every sip its own journey. Amazing. || My favorite whisky. It's so good, and the smell is so great- i kept the bottle just to smell it after i finished the bottle. || Just received my bottle today, it has a nice smokey taste with an undertone which I find reminiscent of saffron. I'm no connoisseur but believe it's a nice whiskey. || Certainly interesting but neither the peat nor the rum finish really stands out in an exceptional way. The flavors aren't anything that can't be found in cheaper scotches. It's not bad, just nothing special. Which for the price warrants the 3 stars.

name: Mortlach 12 Year OldThe Wee Witchie
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Walnut, Dates, Lemon
nose: Rich and deep, with immediate warming, toasty oak tones (wood shavings) and a light peachy element that moves towards honey and then cooked fruits hinting at good depth. Some chestnut helps to add a sweet nutty background alongside hints of wax crayon. This impression of oak, sandalwood, light spice, and fruit - now with some dried berries - slowly gives way to some charred elements, hard (Highland) toffee and some light meatiness. Once this is established (and it takes time) it starts to deepen, earthy, petrichor, (the smell of early autumn), dried blossom, pineapple and bitter orange that itself extends into Terry’s chocolate orange and then cooked plum. As it dries so the woodland gives way to a coal bunker/lichen encrusted logs in a woodpile.
palate: A sweet, almost peachy, concentrated start with a little oak and almost smoky (charred) element. It’s at its most expressive on the mid-palate where you pick out bitter chocolate, marmalade and light tobacco that’s balanced by a puddle of syrup before it deepens further and starts to grip, there’s liquorice, roast chestnut, tree bark, roasting coffee, and a burnt edge which might be the sulphur working its way out. As it develops so you get bourbon biscuit, then the meaty flavours which themselves have the herbal qualities of goat or lamb. The grip loosens, and light gets back in with things getting sweeter and also more spicy.
finish: Quite dry and slightly sooty/ashy with oak (fresh-sawn timber). There’s some plum with an added hint of bitterness.
reviews: Good autumn dram. || Fabulous 12yo from Speyside. Not sure I need to try older expressions from this distillery. The 'Wee Witchie' is as good as anything I've sampled from the region. There's creamy toffee, and a hint of liquorice along with the alcohol on the nose. It's Christmas cake in a glass on the palate as sherried fruits and nuts come through, with a lovely dry finish. One that I'll always have in the collection. One criticism, poor quality cheap plastic seal and poor fitting cork, caused slight leakage on my bottle. Retailer changed without question but something distillery needs to look at. Far too good a product to scrimp on poor quality seal. || Loved it. Smooth with a little burn at the end. Both me and my father enjoyed it. || Mortlach 12 is delicious! Not a spicy dram, but nutty and fruity. Give it a long rest in the glass (20 minutes) and no water. Simply superb. || This is a shockingly good whisky. One of the best I've had. I can't even discard the empty bottle .It too is a good thing.
_text_all: dried fruit vanilla walnut dates lemon fried chicken dim sum monkfish rich and deep with immediate warming toasty oak tones wood shavings and light peachy element that moves towards honey and then cooked fruits hinting at good depth some chestnut helps to add sweet nutty background alongside hints of wax crayon this impression of oak sandalwood light spice and fruit - now with some dried berries - slowly gives way to some charred elements hard highland toffee and some light meatiness once this is established and it takes time it starts to deepen earthy petrichor the smell of early autumn dried blossom pineapple and bitter orange that itself extends into terry chocolate orange and then cooked plum as it dries so the woodland gives way to coal bunker lichen encrusted logs in woodpile sweet almost peachy concentrated start with little oak and almost smoky charred element it at its most expressive on the mid-palate where you pick out bitter chocolate marmalade and light tobacco that balanced by puddle of syrup before it deepens further and starts to grip there liquorice roast chestnut tree bark roasting coffee and burnt edge which might be the sulphur working its way out as it develops so you get bourbon biscuit then the meaty flavours which themselves have the herbal qualities of goat or lamb the grip loosens and light gets back in with things getting sweeter and also more spicy quite dry and slightly sooty ashy with oak fresh-sawn timber there some plum with an added hint of bitterness good autumn dram fabulous yo from speyside not sure need to try older expressions from this distillery the wee witchie is as good as anything ve sampled from the region there creamy toffee and hint of liquorice along with the alcohol on the nose it christmas cake in glass on the palate as sherried fruits and nuts come through with lovely dry finish one that ll always have in the collection one criticism poor quality cheap plastic seal and poor fitting cork caused slight leakage on my bottle retailer changed without question but something distillery needs to look at far too good product to scrimp on poor quality seal loved it smooth with little burn at the end both me and my father enjoyed it mortlach is delicious not spicy dram but nutty and fruity give it long rest in the glass minutes and no water simply superb this is shockingly good whisky one of the best ve had can even discard the empty bottle it too is good thing

name: Loch Dhu 10 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: They claimed it got its colour from the casks it was matured in, that was false,the "bhu"was added by caramel before bottling which led to its being withdrawn making its new rarity collectable.it was a shame really because loch bhu was an excellent dram to be sipped neat as it did not appreciate the addition of any water || Yes,twice and found Loch Dhu the most delightfull whisky ever sampled. || Silky smooth and viscous. EXCELLENT! As best my unsophisticated pallet could tell, licorice, tar, earth, caramel. Looks a bit like old, crankcase oil. 1st taste, given a 1/2 litre. Bought 1 full and 1/2 litre online. Bought a Japanese packaged bottle on Ebay! Now that I've found you, I'll be ordering more! || Peat meets treacle and Guinness, silky smooth and viscous . Superb! || guinness, liquorice, tar, chocolate, earth, treacle, caramel on the (short) finish. interesting but not really worth the price of admission.

name: Old Ballantruan
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: Citrussy, very aromatic. A distant dry smokiness swirling up. A mineral touch (wet pebble). Then a fruity whiff of ripe peaches and pears. All is wrapped in a delicate honeyed veil.
palate: Rich, silky, enticing. Oily, getting drier on the tongue as spices burst out. Some green gage flavours mingling with spices.
reviews: I purchased a bottle at the highland games in Pitlochry after having a "wee dram". I'm not one for peated scotch, but the Old Ballantruan won me over at first sip. I brougha bottlet back to the US to share with friends. It's a beautiful whiskey. || A cracking speyside peaty whisky. I would rate 3 on smoke rather 2. I am a major fan of islay smokey whisky and this one is a definite in the drinks collection! || Tastes great smoke and flavor notes harmonize perfectly. a very delicious smoked whiskey. One of my top smoked whiskeys || I found this to be quite spectacular for the price. The tasting notes are spot on. || Rough with too much caramel and far too pricey for what it is, given that I can buy Laphroaig 10 and Ardbeg 10 cheaper than this.
_text_all: smoke malt praline lemon hazelnut citrussy very aromatic distant dry smokiness swirling up mineral touch wet pebble then fruity whiff of ripe peaches and pears all is wrapped in delicate honeyed veil rich silky enticing oily getting drier on the tongue as spices burst out some green gage flavours mingling with spices lemony drying on ginger purchased bottle at the highland games in pitlochry after having wee dram not one for peated scotch but the old ballantruan won me over at first sip brougha bottlet back to the us to share with friends it beautiful whisky cracking speyside peaty whisky would rate on smoke rather am major fan of islay smoky whisky and this one is definite in the drinks collection tastes great smoke and flavor notes harmonize perfectly very delicious smoked whisky one of my top smoked whiskys found this to be quite spectacular for the price the tasting notes are spot on rough with too much caramel and far too pricey for what it is given that can buy laphroaig and ardbeg cheaper than this

name: Balvenie 16 Year Old French OakPineau Cask Finish
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Apple, Grapefruit, Honey, Ginger, Geranium, Grass
nose: Beautifully balanced light floral notes from lotus and geranium flowers dance between hints of fresh meadow grass and peeled apple skin.
palate: A energizing zing from tangy lemon rind and grapefruit meet the delicate subtle sweetness of glazed fruits and spice from root ginger.
reviews: Perhaps a price range of £70-90 would help it! || At first I thought I had erred in my purchase but after several months I came back to it. I was surprised at how much I began to enjoy it. It certainly has been a nice change from the sherry based malts I have been drinking from Glendronach, Hazelburn and Dalmore. It is a solid bottling from Balvenie and I am glad for my purchase. || Great addition to any French oak whisky lovers profile. Sampled these with 2 other French oak finished bourbons and this one took first!!

name: Glenallachie Distillery Edition
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: This is not quite as smooth as the writing on the box claims, however that said it is a really flavoursome malt and delicious when chilled with ice || Got two bottles of this lovely whiskey on offer half price – £15 each – and thought at that price would try it. Would I have paid full price? Probably; for a single malt it ticks most of the boxes. It’s smooth with a nice warmth that doesn’t overpower. It’s not peaty which is good for me as I don’t like the overly peated (almost dental) taste in some whiskies. It’s on par with Glen Keith or lower-end Jura. If you want a whisky to impress but don’t want to blow your budget, give it a whirl – your guest/recipient won’t be disappointed. || Yes have tried this whisky, it is a lovely dram and is very mild . || Have also tried this and agree with the young age part of previous review.I personally think this is about 8 years old at most and it shows in how spirity it is on the nose.I cant find a lot to say about this , apart from along with the Glen Keith of the same packaging it is a very poor offering from Pernod Ricard for both distilleries.I have said of the Glen Keith bottling that an expression of 10-12 years and 46 abv could showcase both distilleries in a better light. || Amazing how a distillery so close to Aberlour can come up with something so different. It has notes of rhubarb, baked apple, custard, flapjack, vanilla, gooseberry and sherbert. No age statement but it does not feel under-matured - maybe 10 years old or so. Yes it is off the radar a bit but worth buying for something made in vast quantities yet retaining distinctive flavours.

name: Aberlour A'Bunadh Batch 57
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews:
My single favorite bottle, and one I am never without. The variance in flavor between batches is noticeable and welcome - variations on a theme.  This requires a little patience to open up, but is very rewarding once it does. If you are looking to expand your horizons or are new to this kind of brown water, this is an excellent place to start. || Great whisky, has an excellent taste. Highly recomended! One of my favourites. || Id heard alot of good things about abunadh and so was very interested in trying it. I have to admit at first i was quite disappointed, yes there were some lovely rich flavours but all rather mute. I tried it neat and with a little water and both times with around 20 minutes in the glass before tasting. I cannot claim to be an expert by any stretch of the imagination but i expected a greater experience from this whisky (batch 57 ) 

Now a month on with a quater of the bottle gone my opinion has changed. Its a lovely dram, one that i expected it to be. I think the oxidisation has really helped this bottle open up. I highly recommend it, but definitely needs a bit of time and air. || This is a great bottle, the taste is powerfull and i personaly tryed straight and with water and i prefer straight ! The nose the taste and the after tase are givin you all what you was looking for , but for the price go with the aberloir 12! Dont esitate for the powerfull ! || Got my first bottle last month! Fantastic sherried style whisky from aberlour. Definitely needs a little water to take off the burn from 60% but the flavours are so good, Christmas cake, cherrys, chocolate.. so so good just grab a bottle and enjoy!
_text_all: no description no description no description no description my single favorite bottle and one am never without the variance in flavor between batches is noticeable and welcome - variations on theme this requires little patience to open up but is very rewarding once it does if you are looking to expand your horizons or are new to this kind of brown water this is an excellent place to start great whisky has an excellent taste highly recomended one of my favourites id heard alot of good things about abunadh and so was very interested in trying it have to admit at first was quite disappointed yes there were some lovely rich flavours but all rather mute tried it neat and with little water and both times with around minutes in the glass before tasting cannot claim to be an expert by any stretch of the imagination but expected greater experience from this whisky batch now month on with quater of the bottle gone my opinion has changed its lovely dram one that expected it to be think the oxidisation has really helped this bottle open up highly recommend it but definitely needs bit of time and air this is great bottle the taste is powerfull and personaly tryed straight and with water and prefer straight the nose the taste and the after tase are givin you all what you was looking for but for the price go with the aberloir dont esitate for the powerfull got my first bottle last month fantastic sherried style whisky from aberlour definitely needs little water to take off the burn from but the flavours are so good christmas cake cherrys chocolate so so good just grab bottle and enjoy

name: Cragganmore 12 Year OldSmall Bottle
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: An aromatic blast of citrus to begin with – orange and lemon oil – then soft aromas of toffee, roasted almonds and malted biscuits follow. Very clean and appetising, with a gentle floral character.
palate: The fresh citrus notes continue on to the palate, joined by sweet toffee, malt and oat biscuits. Very clean and refreshing.
reviews: Lovely! Says it all. But so easy to drink I have to pace myself! Definitely a must try! || Very fruity, delicate, vivid and vibrant single malt Scotch whisky. Full of character, reveals its personality in every sip both on the nose and palate. Certainly more feminine than masculine, and perfect Scotch for spring/summer days. It should also be noted here that my lady friends with a taste for Scotch claim Cragganmore 12 Year to be their most favorite Scotch for all the reasons listed above. Enjoy!

name: Glenlivet Founder's Reserve
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
nose: Delicate aromas of citrus fruit, notably sweet orange.
palate: Sweet, fruit notes of zesty oranges and pears, with a hint of candy, toffee apples. Well-balanced and exceptionally smooth.
reviews: When an established distillery fills a whiskey into a really nice (!) flask, names it "Founder's Reserve", people would expect a matching quality. This drink does not meet those expectations at all. Raw, scratchy, metallic. The potential is there, but would have needed much more ageing. Overpositioning a product like this, and misleading customers by doing so will alienate fans from this otherwise quite palatable brand. Sorry. || Lovely,smooth tasty,warming. || 3.5. Pleasant dram. Nothing overpowering. You can tell there is some young liquid in here particularly on the nose which carries a little too much alcohol. As with many NAS drams, improves with resting and maybe a bit of ice (shock horror!). Hilarious reading these reviews though. My favourite comments are: - "a good starting whisky", subtly boasting that the reviewer is a seasoned veteran with a highly tuned palate, more used to complex flavours - "there are better blends out there", well yeah... there are some incredible blends out there. - "tastes watered down", well yeah!...its bottled at 40% which means the distillery almost certainly (as with any 40% bottling) added purified water when bottling... watering it down. While I'm at it - please stop slating people for adding water or ice to their dram. Its great. Also - stop harping on about the peatiness coming from the water, its nonesense. Thank you please || I drink it and I like it. But it’s too short on the finish and missing half of the palate. It is a bottle of all of the elements I love about Glenlivet, but too fast and not enough. With no pause in between. || A nice way to enter the single malts world and not just on the price. This is a smooth, gentle and fresh whisky with sweet citric nose notes, specially orange. It has a soft creamy mouthfill and keeps the orange promise with a middle persistence, also apple and candy tastes can be noticed. The finish stays on the smooth range with a spicy touch. On a sunny day, at the beach or by the pool this bottle will work for everyone, specially the non initiated and that's what I guess is the focus of this expression.

good starting whisky subtly boasting that the reviewer is seasoned veteran with highly tuned palate more used to complex flavours - there are better blends out there well yeah there are some incredible blends out there - tastes watered down well yeah its bottled at which means the distillery almost certainly as with any bottling added purified water when bottling watering it down while at it - please stop slating people for adding water or ice to their dram its great also - stop harping on about the peatiness coming from the water its nonesense thank you please drink it and like it but it too short on the finish and missing half of the palate it is bottle of all of the elements love about glenlivet but too fast and not enough with no pause in between nice way to enter the single malts world and not just on the price this is smooth gentle and fresh whisky with sweet citric nose notes specially orange it has soft creamy mouthfill and keeps the orange promise with middle persistence also apple and candy tastes can be noticed the finish stays on the smooth range with spicy touch on sunny day at the beach or by the pool this bottle will work for everyone specially the non initiated and that what guess is the focus of this expression

name: 20 Year Old Speyside Cognac FinishWhisky Works
characters: Violet, Grapefruit, Milk Chocolate, Cream, Strawberry, Ginger
nose: Barley sugar and toffee, candy necklaces and sweet butter. Floral notes develop along with fragrant grassiness. Soft notes of mint fondant hide at the back with building butter, toffee and butterscotch notes over the top.
palate: Candied flowers lead, with Glacier Mints, sherbet lemons and sharp apples to follow. Gently spicy oak, ginger and a touch of polished wood develop. Hob-nob oats and sweet butter biscuits develop, balanced by sweet royal icing and touch of sour apple.
finish: Soft but long, with a burst of sawdust fading to leave mint cream, apple sauce a touch of old damp oak. Sweet butter icing lingers.
reviews: Really nice whisky. Aromatic, sweet and fruity. Im usually an Islay drinker but this makes me want to change sides. Would love to see a sample set of all their whiskies!

name: Glen Moray Peated
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Leather, Smoke, Vanilla, Cream, Rhubarb, Cinnamon
nose: Layers of peat with background of vanilla. Tangy rhubarb and hints of leather.
reviews: I thought this was a great buy, very drinkable and not as peaty as some of the Islay malts. Well worth the price and let the whisky snobs stay with their overpriced bottles. || This is such a pleasant change from the "smack in the mouth" peat you generally get from Islay. Because the peat used to dry the malt in Glen Moray is cut in the highlands, its constituent plants are very different from the coastal plants found on Islay. Resulting in a lovely peaty nose that is unmistakable, that is followed with a smoother and sweeter taste yet still quite spicy. For the current price, there are few peated malts to compare, and pretty much nothing from the Highlands that comes close. It's easily worth double, simply because Highland Peated Whisky is so rare. || Having bought this on a whim for £18 in a supermarket six months ago I've just got round to trying it.Bearing in mind I don't like Speyside as a rule this was out of character.Anyhow,credit where credit is due this is quite nice.Lovely peaty taste with a refreshing rhubarb undertone.I will quite happily polish this bottle off and buy another.3.75/5 || The character/personality is very good, but in the palate its youth is obvious. The smoke doen't quite cover up the "spirity" taste. Not a lot of complexity here, but still a very nice dram. || Yes I have tried this whiskey and I really like it as I like Smokey whiskey
_text_all: leather smoke vanilla cream rhubarb cinnamon layers of peat with background of vanilla tangy rhubarb and hints of leather no description long sweet and spicy thought this was great buy very drinkable and not as peaty as some of the islay malts well worth the price and let the whisky snobs stay with their overpriced bottles this is such pleasant change from the smack in the mouth peat you generally get from islay because the peat used to dry the malt in glen moray is cut in the highlands its constituent plants are very different from the coastal plants found on islay resulting in lovely peaty nose that is unmistakable that is followed with smoother and sweeter taste yet still quite spicy for the current price there are few peated malts to compare and pretty much nothing from the highlands that comes close it easily worth double simply because highland peated whisky is so rare having bought this on whim for in supermarket six months ago ve just got round to trying it bearing in mind don like speyside as rule this was out of character anyhow credit where credit is due this is quite nice lovely peaty taste with refreshing rhubarb undertone will quite happily polish this bottle off and buy another the character personality is very good but in the palate its youth is obvious the smoke doen quite cover up the spirity taste not lot of complexity here but still very nice dram yes have tried this whisky and really like it as like smoky whisky

name: Glen Moray Port Cask Finish
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Honey, Dark Chocolate, Nutmeg, Lemon, Cinnamon, Oak
nose: First impressions are of toasted vanilla and subtle hints of oak. Aromas of rich dried fruits and leather follow, laced with dark chocolate and blackberries.
finish: The finish is smooth with soft oak and honey sweetness lingering gently on the tongue. The spice continues to tingle and dark chocolate flavours develop to give luxurious texture and a fitting finale to an elegant whisky.
reviews: A port finished scotch for a reasonable price? Count me in! Dried plums, apricots and peach, with some oak in the background. It tastes very young and definitely needs a drop or two of water to open up. Quite pleasant once you get past the harshness. You can definitely taste the port cask influence here. || I was quite hopeful. "Decent for the price" was what I'd come to expect based on the reviews. No significant nose to speak of. Thin body, overly sweet with not much else to offset it. Had two drinks, and poured it out. A waste, really, but I was rather disappointed. Your mileage may vary. || Solid for the price, but I don’t love the flavor. It’s peachy, kinda cheap. I’m sure this is better quality than Dewars White, but tastes similar. || Not too strong, oaky taste. Pleasant to drink. || Amazing for the price. I get it, sweeter-end whiskys are not for everyone, but I like it. Works very well as a dessert whisky too.
_text_all: honey dark chocolate nutmeg lemon cinnamon oak first impressions are of toasted vanilla and subtle hints of oak aromas of rich dried fruits and leather follow laced with dark chocolate and blackberries no description the finish is smooth with soft oak and honey sweetness lingering gently on the tongue the spice continues to tingle and dark chocolate flavours develop to give luxurious texture and fitting finale to an elegant whisky port finished scotch for reasonable price count me in dried plums apricots and peach with some oak in the background it tastes very young and definitely needs drop or two of water to open up quite pleasant once you get past the harshness you can definitely taste the port cask influence here was quite hopeful decent for the price was what come to expect based on the reviews no significant nose to speak of thin body overly sweet with not much else to offset it had two drinks and poured it out waste really but was rather disappointed your mileage may vary solid for the price but don love the flavor it peachy kinda cheap sure this is better quality than dewars white but tastes similar not too strong oaky taste pleasant to drink amazing for the price get it sweeter-end whiskys are not for everyone but like it works very well as dessert whisky too

name: Benrinnes 199626 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cinnamon, Vanilla, Apple, Fruit Cake, Cream, Oak
nose: Light fruitcake with glacé cherries and baking spice, slathered with butter. Sweet apples and pears follow along with a touch of malt loaf, barley sugar and vanilla cream. After a few minutes strawberries push through the cream, followed by salted butter.
palate: Big sweetness to start: mint fondant and crème pâtissière. Polished oak and woody spice build, balanced by stewed apple and buttered toast.

name: Glen Keith 199329 Year Old Signatory for The Whisky Exchange
characters: Malt, Toffee, Apple, Mango, Cream, Banana
nose: Sweet cream with apple, mango and a touch of olive oil – green and grassy. Barley-sugar sweetness and pink shrimp sweets are backed up by gentle maltiness.
palate: Meaty grain, mint fondant and rich butter cream. The grain falls beneath the cream as gentle toffee sauce notes develop. Then comes a wave of fruit: apples, pears, bananas and slightly underripe mangoes.
finish: Salty butter and white toast followed by toffee, apples and soft spice.

name: Glen Grant 15 Year Old Batch Strength First Edition
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling

reviews: Got this in a tasting pack. A big pear hit and hint of melon on the nose. Beautiful light colour. Delightfully oily in the glass. After the immediate hit of alcohol, vanilla explodes on the pallet, then spice on a long lingering finish. Added a drop of water to compare. Brings the melon through more, but on the palate, not as good for me. Dampens the alcohol but loses flavour. Definitely one for sipping straight up. Happy to purchase. It's a lovely Speyside dram.

name: Tamnavulin German Pinot Noir Cask
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: I would say this is actually quite a good whisky. I can only imagine this is a young whisky but it honestly doesn’t taste that way. You can spend £50 for something like Filey Bay or a bit less for Cotswold and this is honestly just better. It’s much richer in fruitiness, I can’t seem to find that ethanol flavour. I’d say it’s the sweet brother of the woody Black Bottle. In fact, mixing the pair in a barrel could be quite special It’s not 5 star because it’s not complex. But the one thing it does do, especially for the price (22 quid for me) is brilliant || Good crowd pleaser, sweeter notes and less smokey for whiskey beginners. The red wine flavour comes through in the scent and adds to a great all round taste. || Now this one is a waste of time.Thank the good lord I only paid £20 for it.Got a finish drier than Noel Coward

name: Aberlour A'Bunadh Batch 59
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: Not as good as batch 55, but still excellent || This batch 59 is quite disappointing compared to earlier batches. I’ve tried most batches up to 52, and I regarded them as very consistent and always a favourite for me. There is a definite difference with this, still warming, but harsh and not much of a sherry hit on the nose or taste. || Best whiskey from speyside hands down. Came to the US of A really fast || The 59 is a  far less complex and has less depth than the 58.  Sherry notes are diminished substantially. There is a predominance of bitter dark chocolate and spices. The  impression I got was that the spirit hadn’t spent long enough in the barrel or that the barrels were third fill. I was disappointed but as the a’bunadh 59 is widely available at a reduced price it is probably still worth buying...but only just. || This is hardly less alcoholic at nearly 61% than earlier versions.  Adding still water is a must and brings out the  flavours of Citrus fruits and Spices.  As it lingers rich Christmas cake with hints of Ginger  come to the fore with an added subtle influence of polished leather.  A little masterpiece.
_text_all: no description no description no description no description not as good as batch but still excellent this batch is quite disappointing compared to earlier batches ve tried most batches up to and regarded them as very consistent and always favourite for me there is definite difference with this still warming but harsh and not much of sherry hit on the nose or taste best whisky from speyside hands down came to the us of really fast the is far less complex and has less depth than the sherry notes are diminished substantially there is predominance of bitter dark chocolate and spices the impression got was that the spirit hadn spent long enough in the barrel or that the barrels were third fill was disappointed but as the bunadh is widely available at reduced price it is probably still worth buying but only just this is hardly less alcoholic at nearly than earlier versions adding still water is must and brings out the flavours of citrus fruits and spices as it lingers rich christmas cake with hints of ginger come to the fore with an added subtle influence of polished leather little masterpiece

name: Speyburn 10 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
reviews: tried one of these in a pub in Cumbria, it was awful but then i got info to the opposite so i bought a bottle. i was really surprised as it is quite a mellow, sweet on the nose, slightly woody dram. methinks someone in a Cumbrian pub hast pulled a fast one, this is definitely the whisly i was served in said establishment. || Smells and tastes exactly like a hospital ward, avoid. || Yes. Affordable speyside single malt. NOT heavy on the smoke/peat. nice & mellow. One of my favorites along with Dewers 12yr blended. || A decent dram, smooth with gentle flavours of Heather citrus & toffee in that order. The spirit is prominent in tasting but I wouldn't add any water, still a good introduction into single malt whisky. || I bought this on a whim because it was more affordable than Glenfiddich 15 solera, I was really amazed at how wonderfully smooth and supple the texture was, and how rich and noteworthy the nose compared to the Glenmorangie 12 I have open. I have been enjoying this bottles evolution as it mellows even more with air, and I found it needed no water to soften. Highly recommended to those with a new-to-scotch palates.

name: Glenfiddich 30 Year OldSuspended Time Re-imagined Time Series
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Oak, Honey, Dried Fruit, Rose, Heather, Nutmeg
nose: Aspects of apple: sharp green apples, toffee apples, apples with toffee sauce. They're joined by barley sugar, sherbet lemons, butterscotch and butter icing. Leafy and fresh-cut grass notes develop, along with creamy toffee, hay and Rich Tea biscuits, with a hint of Garibaldi biscuit following close behind.
palate: Soft rounded and buttery. Old polished oak leads, with creamy toffee following. Spice and sharp apple softens to bright apple sauce with gentle spicing. Spun sugar, barley sugar and gentle char are balanced, supported by a touch sappy oak. Crème brûlée with a singed top rounds things out.
finish: Cinnamon and allspice with apples, skins and pips included. Sweet polished oak, soft char and toffee apples linger, with a hint of aniseed ball heat.

name: Glenrothes 18 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Orange, Vanilla, Pear, Rose, Ginger, Almond
nose: Orange oil, vanilla pods, pear and almonds.
palate: Sweet, ginger, rose water, pears and vanilla.
reviews: Truly delicious! Has notes of vanilla, ginger, rose, orange and pear, as advertised. In addition, this new Soleo Collection release has an amazingly deep taste - and aroma - of soft, chewy caramel. The kind of soft, chewy, homemade, melts-in-your-mouth individually wrapped caramel sold occasionally at speciality stores. This was my first Glenrothes, and it’s a knock-out. Not a sherry-bomb, but rather the perfect amount of sweetness, with far more depth than I expected based on color alone (as compared to some of the other 18-year old whiskies I’ve imbibed over the years). This one is a keeper and will now occupy the sacred top-shelf area of my cupboard along with three or four other elderly (18-25 year) Scottish cousins. Also, hats off to the great folks at Whisky Exchange, whose shipments always arrive quickly and in perfect condition to my home In Hillsboro, Oregon (USA).

name: Tamdhu 21 Year Old
main_info: speyside single malt scotch whiskydistillery bottling
characters: Sherry, Orange, Dark Chocolate, Oak, Figs
nose: Dunnage warehouses and sniffed sherry-cask bungholes – about as close to smelling a whisky in a warehouse as you can get while not in a warehouse. Spiced sponge cake with raisins, sultanas and mixed peel. Malt loaf, fruit loaf, baking spice, sour cherry jam and brown-sugar cookies.

finish: Cherry jam and baking spice, with stewed apples and lingering damp oak.

name: Hakushu Distiller's Reserve
characters: Grapefruit, Smoke, Melon, Mixed Herb, Eucalyptus, Apple
nose: Quite herbaceous. Green fruit, mint, cucumber, pine, grassy, spearmint. Just loads of green fruit in this one.
palate: Loads of green things coming out of here! Mint, cucumber, green fruit, grapefruit and just a touch of smoke at the back. Dave Broom got yuzu…I’ve never heard of yuzu….
finish: Light, delicate, refreshing and some subtle smoke.
reviews:
I agree with the other reviews. It tasted clean with no after taste. The cucumber reference is well deserved as it tastes fresh. 
Easily drunk neat. Be careful as you’ll drink too much! || Under-rated in my opinion- mainly, it’s very interesting in flavour, not a deep layered whisky but also unlike most, so I liked it for that reason || A young lively bright whisky.  On the nose: a cool breathe of mint and vanilla coming from the strong interaction  with American oak, the Japanese change of seasons is truly present in this malt. Floral perfume, melon. Some hints of smoke and earthy moss. On the palate: creamy and clear as spring water, very in line with the nose. Not very deep, but lively and focussed.  It is said to contain a lightly peated young spirit above 8yo and a strongly peated spirit above 18yo. The younger whisky sets the tone: a great serene character which reflects the pine forests  around the distillery (and less complex than the Hakushu 12yo). || A truly special whisky. It's very Green, a start that commences with a fruity mouth like biting info a fresh apple after settling swallowing ice cold water with lime and mint in it.... Then a subtle lapsang souchong flavoured shortbread finish.   I can't do this justice and I'm normally very verbose || This is our favourite Japanese whisky. It is clean and refreshing. We once visited the distillery where Hakushu was produced, and fell in love with this. They did something called 'highball from the wood' using Hakushu, which was sublime. Last year, we discovered as its popularity soared, Suntory had run out of the liquid and stopped shipping Hakushu as well as Yamazaki. I was therefore very pleased to find a reasonably priced bottle of Hakushu on Whisky Exchange.
_text_all: grapefruit smoke melon mixed herb eucalyptus apple quite herbaceous green fruit mint cucumber pine grassy spearmint just loads of green fruit in this one loads of green things coming out of here mint cucumber green fruit grapefruit and just touch of smoke at the back dave broom got yuzu ve never heard of yuzu light delicate refreshing and some subtle smoke agree with the other reviews it tasted clean with no after taste the cucumber reference is well deserved as it tastes fresh easily drunk neat be careful as you ll drink too much under-rated in my opinion- mainly it very interesting in flavour not deep layered whisky but also unlike most so liked it for that reason young lively bright whisky on the nose cool breathe of mint and vanilla coming from the strong interaction with american oak the japanese change of seasons is truly present in this malt floral perfume melon some hints of smoke and earthy moss on the palate creamy and clear as spring water very in line with the nose not very deep but lively and focussed it is said to contain lightly peated young spirit above yo and strongly peated spirit above yo the younger whisky sets the tone great serene character which reflects the pine forests around the distillery and less complex than the hakushu yo truly special whisky it very green start that commences with fruity mouth like biting info fresh apple after settling swallowing ice cold water with lime and mint in it then subtle lapsang souchong flavoured shortbread finish can do this justice and normally very verbose this is our favourite japanese whisky it is clean and refreshing we once visited the distillery where hakushu was produced and fell in love with this they did something called highball from the wood using hakushu which was sublime last year we discovered as its popularity soared suntory had run out of the liquid and stopped shipping hakushu as well as yamazaki was therefore very pleased to find reasonably priced bottle of hakushu on whisky exchange

reviews: to spicee and to harsh. i think its over hiped and ovepriced. few years back when 12 years old hibiki was about £50 , price was more reasonable... || Excellent whisky, with an unique flavor, mild, gentle, floral, fruity and sandalwood notes, thanks to the influence of mizunara casks. I rate this as the best whisky outside Scotland in the NAS segment. Although I really enjoyed it, I didn't think it was a significant improvement on my usual single malt. || Striking amber colour with a pleasant aroma, drank over ice it was smooth with a subtle bite but no prolonged after taste. Very nice over all and would be a welcome gift. || Great tasting whiskey

Back in the day when you could find a bottle for £60 I would just about stretch to buying one (on a special occasion). But for £135 I just don’t think it’s worth it, you can find whisky which is just as good for far cheaper, and if your budget for a bottle is £135 you can find something truly special! Very pleasant and easy to drink, but not worth the price by a long way.
