name: Yamazaki Distiller's Reserve
nose: The wine cask seems to dominate the nose here with strawberries and red fruit taking centre stage. However, sitting quietly in the background is the incense from the mizunara, a hint of dried fruit from the sherry cask and a touch of coconut.
palate: An abundance of red fruit again, with raspberries, strawberries and even redcurrants coming through, although there’s more dimensions to this than the first wine cask sample that we tried. White peach, a hint of wood and spice, back-up notes of red cherries and candied fruits all come into play here as well.
finish: Relatively long finish with vanilla and sweet spice dancing around the tongue.
reviews: I preferred this over their 12YO. || Bought this bottle. Very nice really smooth and lovely t drink || Well balanced, excellent flavors and good with ice shaken or on its own! One of the best around. || Absolutely beautiful took this wiskey home from Japan. Its rich and fruity lovely nose of vanilla fruity raisins touch of oak. || Terrible

name: Suntory Toki
characters: Apple, Grape, Grapefruit, Mint, White Pepper, Ginger
finish: Subtly sweet and spicy finish with a hint of vanilla oak, white pepper and ginger.
reviews: This is Suntory's cheaper whisky intended for drinking as a highball, so not surprising people aren't keen on drinking it neat || This is not my first time drinking Japanese whisky, but it might be my last now. This is very poor, very hot and much too young. Japanese whisky used to be a much better product. What a shame. || I have tried several different Japanese whiskies. This is my least favorite. It is too strong to drink neat. I will try it as a highball where I think it will be much more enjoyable. A few notes of fruit and herbs but falls short on complexity and refinement. || This was my first time trying a Japanese whisky, and I'm very impressed. Pleasant aromas of honey and pine resin that carry through on to the palate, where they're joined by floral notes, a hint of citrus, and a slight pepper spice. I'm definitely in unfamiliar territory here, as my go-to is any bottle full of smoke and peat from Islay, but I found this very pleasant and easy to drink. I'll certainly be back for more! || First time trying out the Japanese whisky brands and I must say this isn't bad introduction for the price. Still a scotch whisky drinker, but I cant wait and try Suntory other brands of the Asian market.

name: Nikka Coffey Grain Whisky
nose: Sweeter and fruitier than the Coffey Malt, this is has oodles of sweet spice, mango and papaya aromas, candied orange peel and coconut.
palate: Toffee popcorn, with more of that heady citrus and tropical fruit. Quite a mouthful.
finish: Not especially long lasting; rich oak and marmalade notes dominate.
reviews: Lovely smooth and mellow whisky. || This is my 2nd Japanese I've tried out and it was great. It was strong at first but with some distilled water it had the sweet taste of some fruit, and bit of vanilla. Excellent work at the Nikka distillery. || Delicious! Tropical fruits and spice. All enveloping with a lot going on. A dram you keep wanting to come back to || The sweetness is just magical! || Excellent

name: Yoichi Single Malt
characters: Smoke, Seashell, Salt (powder), Lemon, Apple, Oak
nose: Full-bodied, smooth. A mellow peat softly coats the aromatic palette at first, growing more powerful with time, as smoke, soot and salty notes transcend the initial nose. The aromas then evolve towards candied citrus fruit (lemon, orange), black liquorice and spices (nutmeg, ginger), and opens up with roots and dried twig aromas. Heady and floral (carnation, iris), it grows increasingly complex.
palate: Firm, powerful. A well-balanced attack gives equal footing to aromas of peat, smoke, spices, fresh fruit (melon, kiwi) and nuts (almond, walnut), which it delivers in spades. The mid-palate starts off with chocolate notes, but the peat soon takes the lead once again.
finish: Long, silky. Extremely mature, it overflows with ripe fruit (pear, Mirabelle plum, apple). The peat starts taking on an herbaceous and malty character, while the salty flavours gives the finish plenty of depth and coastal freshness. The final nose offers menthol, spicy (coriander, dill) and earthy (leather, chestnuts) notes.
reviews: Tried this at the Whisky Fringe and have it my vote for best dram. Fruity and smooth. Didn't even add water, a lovely dram || Smooth || Very smooth and balanced and very good value for money || This isnt a bad product. In fact it retails for ~25 quid in Japan, which is about right. In the UK you'd be far better off with some fine Scottish malt if you're spending 70 odd pounds, imho. Still its a reasonable drink you can buy at the local (japanese) supermarket. I bought 2 yesterday and 2 Miyagikyo-the same price and same reasoning. Its cheap and reasonable. Dont expect a song and dance. || Extremely smooth and dry. Strong taste and extremely pleasant aftertaste. My favorite whiskey.
_text_all: smoke seashell salt powder lemon apple oak full-bodied smooth mellow peat softly coats the aromatic palette at first growing more powerful with time as smoke soot and salty notes transcend the initial nose the aromas then evolve towards candied citrus fruit lemon orange black liquorice and spices nutmeg ginger and opens up with roots and dried twig aromas heady and floral carnation iris it grows increasingly complex firm powerful well-balanced attack gives equal footing to aromas of peat smoke spices fresh fruit melon kiwi and nuts almond walnut which it delivers in spades the mid-palate starts off with chocolate notes but the peat soon takes the lead once again long silky extremely mature it overflows with ripe fruit pear mirabelle plum apple the peat starts taking on an herbaceous and malty character while the salty flavours gives the finish plenty of depth and coastal freshness the final nose offers menthol spicy coriander dill and earthy leather chestnuts notes tried this at the whisky fringe and have it my vote for best dram fruity and smooth didn even add water lovely dram smooth very smooth and balanced and very good value for money this isnt bad product in fact it retails for quid in japan which is about right in the uk you be far better off with some fine scottish malt if you re spending odd pounds imho still its reasonable drink you can buy at the local japanese supermarket bought yesterday and miyagikyo-the same price and same reasoning its cheap and reasonable dont expect song and dance extremely smooth and dry strong taste and extremely pleasant aftertaste my favorite whisky

name: Miyagikyo Single Malt
nose: Full-flavoured, rich. Initially, concentrated iris notes hint at the extreme intensity of the nose. It then develops aromas of malted barley, exotic fruit (banana), liquorice and camphor. Notes of burnt wood and ash progressively settle over the aromatic palette. Long after, white flowers and beeswax make an appearance.
palate: Firm, lively. Malted barley is at the heart of the palate, coated in herbaceous, liquorice, spiced (ginger, cinnamon) and chocolate tones. Very elegant, the mid-palate also delivers plenty of energy and as it draws to a close, fresh tobacco leaves and coconut intertwine to create a natural symphony of aromas.
finish: Long, soft. It evokes the scent of wilted roses. Fine tannins balance its tangy character (lemon, grapefruit). It lingers on notes of tobacco, spices (cardamom, ginger), toasted nuts and stewed fruits (apple, damson). The final nose reveals exotic notes (lychee).
reviews: Bloody well fantastic || Thin body as in description, but I like the taste....not particularly complex and there are a lot better whiskies out there for this price || Smooth floral notes || Not worth the price tag at all! Very young spirits used, flavours are one dimensional. Overall this whisky is very forgettable. Unfortunately, Japanese whisky's popularity is having a negative effect on the quality as distilleries are struggling to keep up with demand. || Shared the bottle with friends. A great Sunday afternoon lunch finished with a very good Japanese single malt.
_text_all: cinnamon ginger tobacco coconut apple full-flavoured rich initially concentrated iris notes hint at the extreme intensity of the nose it then develops aromas of malted barley exotic fruit banana liquorice and camphor notes of burnt wood and ash progressively settle over the aromatic palette long after white flowers and beeswax make an appearance firm lively malted barley is at the heart of the palate coated in herbaceous liquorice spiced ginger cinnamon and chocolate tones very elegant the mid-palate also delivers plenty of energy and as it draws to close fresh tobacco leaves and coconut intertwine to create natural symphony of aromas long soft it evokes the scent of wilted roses fine tannins balance its tangy character lemon grapefruit it lingers on notes of tobacco spices cardamom ginger toasted nuts and stewed fruits apple damson the final nose reveals exotic notes lychee bloody well fantastic thin body as in description but like the taste not particularly complex and there are lot better whiskies out there for this price smooth floral notes not worth the price tag at all very young spirits used flavours are one dimensional overall this whisky is very forgettable unfortunately japanese whisky popularity is having negative effect on the quality as distilleries are struggling to keep up with demand shared the bottle with friends great sunday afternoon lunch finished with very good japanese single malt

name: Hakushu 12 Year Old
nose: Honey, lemon and a little ginger.
palate: Delicacy to the fore. A breakfast dram if there were ever one.
finish: Fruity and sweet. Ripe cherry plums, almond milk, acacia honey.
reviews: 2nd bottle of Japanese whisky and my favorite. Added one ice cube on recommendation and added another level of complexity and balance. Loved it! || My absolute favourite fr the Suntory stable. A whisky for contemplation when time stood still as the world goes by. || My first foray into the Japanese single malts (all other Jap whiskies I've tried to date have been blends) and this did *not* disappoint. Very light color, a bit more on the nose than I'm used to for the Jap stuff but wow what delightful flavours. So well balanced and refined. Subtle smokiness and peat with the slight sweetness of the pear as a delicious aftertaste. An ice cube or two gives you 3 or 4 different drinks as the water seemingly opens up different compartments of this complex, and yet light/delicate single malt. Definitely at the top of my list of Japanese whisky thus far. An easy 5 stars. || My first foray into the Japanese single malts (all other Jap whiskies I've tried to date have been blends) and this did *not* disappoint. Very light color, a bit more on the nose than I'm used to for the Jap stuff but wow what delightful flavours. So well balanced and refined. Subtle smokiness and peat with the slight sweetness of the pear as a delicious aftertaste. An ice cube or two gives you 3 or 4 different drinks as the water seemingly opens up different compartments of this complex, and yet light/delicate single malt. Definitely at the top of my list of Japanese whisky thus far. An easy 5 stars. || I had heard that Japanese whiskey was something to behold. I was in the market for my usual Bowmore and Lagavulin but felt compelled to pick up a bottle to see what the Japanese with a single malt. WOW!!! I was blown away after the first sip! Light, citrus up front followed by a smooth sweetness. The perfect dram for a hot summer evening in Arizona. I highly recommend his masterful whiskey.

name: Ichiro's Malt Double Distilleries(46.5%)
reviews: Have wanted to get a taste of the legendary Hanyu and Chichibu distilleries from Japanese whisky rockstar Akuto-san, but prices for their ultra-limited single malts and single casks are crazy, despite being often just aged for 3-5 years. It's hard to separate the hype from the substance unless you taste it for yourself. I found it to have a pretty strong initial oaky impact on the tongue, but a wonderful complexity of flavors and strong finish. I don't have the nose to give more tasting notes, but suffice to say it was a unique experience and worth the wait and price. || I was pleasantly surprised. Definitely worth the wait.

name: Kanosuke Single Malt 2023 Limited Edition
characters: Cinnamon, Orange, Black tea, Custard, Banana, Peat smoke
nose: Raisins, gravel and cooling cast-iron stoves. Brown sugar and sultanas build with a touch of liquorice and barbecue wood smoke. Chocolate and toasty bread notes develop.
palate: Rich and oily, with gentle heat and chocolatey smoke. Log fires and singed raisins follow, along with cherry jam and green apples. Earthiness hides underneath, alongside more chocolate and hints of mint and moss.
finish: Creamy chocolate, cherry jam and cinnamon spice, with lingering clove and baked apple.
reviews: Absolutely love this. || The first time I will be trying

name: Shirakawa 1958
nose: Resinous, slight dry earth, dried citrus peels, a hint of wax. Aromatic. A drop of water makes it more vibrant and also shows clear maturity as well as a hint of incense. Exotic.
palate: The palate is expansive with a succulent texture and hints of fragrant grass. Fruits emerge in the middle. Layered, spiced, and dry. Water brings out ash from an incense burner, a satisfying mouthfeel and surprisingly perky acidity.
finish: Nicely balanced and persistent on the finish which picks up mint flavouring and makes it more camphor-like.
reviews: Lovely smooth whiskey with a gorgeous fruity aftertaste delicious. || It is definitely a refined and luxurious whiskey. It is also quite different in that the nose is more exotic than fruity. In the perfume world nose is roughly split between floral aromas, rose, lavender etc and exotic musk resinous, sandalwood or spice. The 1958 is out and out exotic, musky and just a touch of lemon. It benefits from a touch of water to open up those exotics but when it does, oh yes, wonderful.
_text_all: lemon grass wax resin mint resinous slight dry earth dried citrus peels hint of wax aromatic drop of water makes it more vibrant and also shows clear maturity as well as hint of incense exotic the palate is expansive with succulent texture and hints of fragrant grass fruits emerge in the middle layered spiced and dry water brings out ash from an incense burner satisfying mouthfeel and surprisingly perky acidity nicely balanced and persistent on the finish which picks up mint flavouring and makes it more camphor-like lovely smooth whisky with gorgeous fruity aftertaste delicious it is definitely refined and luxurious whisky it is also quite different in that the nose is more exotic than fruity in the perfume world nose is roughly split between floral aromas rose lavender etc and exotic musk resinous sandalwood or spice the is out and out exotic musky and just touch of lemon it benefits from touch of water to open up those exotics but when it does oh yes wonderful

name: The Whisky Exchange 37 Year Old Blended MaltGastronomy Selection
main_info: blended malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
nose: Fine Devon fudge and butter toffee, made with milk from undisturbed cows, the finest hand-spun cane sugar and sea-salted, long-cultured farmhouse butter. Freshly shelled hazelnuts and Swiss milk chocolate follow, a crunch-laden enrobing with a sprinkling of finely julienned orange zest. The creaminess builds, packed with gentle Madagascan vanilla character and hints of cream-laden coffee: thick, dark, sweet Rwandan beans, brewed over flame in a Japanese siphon.
palate: The notes of creamy sweetness return, rolling over unsnapped single-origin chocolate shards into a pool of bobbing windfall apples: tart Granny Smith and sweet Pink Lady with a handful of transatlantic Honeycrisp. The nutty notes develop: hazelnuts from the bottom of the bowl with lightly toasted Spanish almonds, all lightly dusted with soft, golden caster sugar. Crunchy spun-sugar nests are draped over thinly sliced conference pears and freshly malted Golden Promise barley. Beeswax-polished oak is sprinkled with gently bruised mint leaves.
finish: Rich, baked-apple purée builds in waves, lingering beyond developing mint and creamy caramel. Chocolate water-ganache, let down with cream, leads to polished oak off-cuts and honey-baked vanilla pods.
reviews: 37 year old malt whisky for £119 - TWE take a bow! On the nose, old leather & dusty library books w/ a little hessian & apple pie. A thick & waxy arrival is followed by flavours of milk chocolate, dried mango & juicy sultanas. Unbelievable value ?? || Was ok in my steak pepper sauce. || This is easily the best whisky I have never had!! The subtly is so in your face that it comes in huge waves of nothingness. My one disappointment with this bottle is that I get no buzz even after drinking nearly the entire bottle in one sitting.
_text_all: hazelnut toffee caramel apple pear fine devon fudge and butter toffee made with milk from undisturbed cows the finest hand-spun cane sugar and sea-salted long-cultured farmhouse butter freshly shelled hazelnuts and swiss milk chocolate follow crunch-laden enrobing with sprinkling of finely julienned orange zest the creaminess builds packed with gentle madagascan vanilla character and hints of cream-laden coffee thick dark sweet rwandan beans brewed over flame in japanese siphon the notes of creamy sweetness return rolling over unsnapped single-origin chocolate shards into pool of bobbing windfall apples tart granny smith and sweet pink lady with handful of transatlantic honeycrisp the nutty notes develop hazelnuts from the bottom of the bowl with lightly toasted spanish almonds all lightly dusted with soft golden caster sugar crunchy spun-sugar nests are draped over thinly sliced conference pears and freshly malted golden promise barley beeswax-polished oak is sprinkled with gently bruised mint leaves rich baked-apple pur builds in waves lingering beyond developing mint and creamy caramel chocolate water-ganache let down with cream leads to polished oak off-cuts and honey-baked vanilla pods year old malt whisky for - twe take bow on the nose old leather dusty library books little hessian apple pie thick waxy arrival is followed by flavours of milk chocolate dried mango juicy sultanas unbelievable value was ok in my steak pepper sauce this is easily the best whisky have never had the subtly is so in your face that it comes in huge waves of nothingness my one disappointment with this bottle is that get no buzz even after drinking nearly the entire bottle in one sitting

name: Dad's Dram Blended MaltThe Whisky Exchange
main_info: blended malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
characters: Apple, Caramel, Pastries, Gooseberry, Toffee, Milk Chocolate
nose: Baked apples, caramel sauce, spiced shortbread, poached pears, baking spice and hints of polished oak. Fresher notes of crunchy apple, gooseberry and redcurrants develop alongside soft ginger nut biscuit touches and a little bit of milk chocolate.
palate: Apples and pears to start: baked, poached and in a pie. The pastry is gently spiced, with cinnamon and nutmeg, dusted with brown sugar and served with a dollop of sharp apple sauce. Creamy toffee sauce notes build, along with hints of vanilla custard and raisins.
finish: Sweet apples and a touch of granny smith apples, with gooseberries, green leaves and a touch of wax-polished oak.
_text_all: apple caramel pastries gooseberry toffee milk chocolate baked apples caramel sauce spiced shortbread poached pears baking spice and hints of polished oak fresher notes of crunchy apple gooseberry and redcurrants develop alongside soft ginger nut biscuit touches and little bit of milk chocolate apples and pears to start baked poached and in pie the pastry is gently spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg dusted with brown sugar and served with dollop of sharp apple sauce creamy toffee sauce notes build along with hints of vanilla custard and raisins sweet apples and touch of granny smith apples with gooseberries green leaves and touch of wax-polished oak

name: Monkey Shoulder
nose: Zesty orange meets mellow vanilla, honey and spiced oak.
reviews: Better than Pinch and other high priced Scotch. || My go to whisky when I feel like a dram of a night, or a cheering glass with a friend. At this level I rate it top of the class! || Sweat smooth creamy vanilla mild spice. Very subtle easy drinking, don't expect the complexity of malts costing twice the price. || Great for the price. Good enough to drink on it's own yet great for cocktails as well. || Very plain taste, not for seasoned drinkers. Lacks complexity. Very smooth and easy to drink though.
_text_all: orange vanilla honey oak zesty orange meets mellow vanilla honey and spiced oak no description super smooth better than pinch and other high priced scotch my go to whisky when feel like dram of night or cheering glass with friend at this level rate it top of the class sweat smooth creamy vanilla mild spice very subtle easy drinking don expect the complexity of malts costing twice the price great for the price good enough to drink on it own yet great for cocktails as well very plain taste not for seasoned drinkers lacks complexity very smooth and easy to drink though

name: Compass Box The Peat Monster
nose: Elegant peat smoke with coastal brine, orchard fruit and singed spice.
palate: Smoky and earthy peat, sweet tropical fruit touches and floral notes.
finish: Sweetness lingers, layered with smoke, fruit and delicate meadow-grass character.
reviews: This is my favourite whisky.. || Smooth. Sea spray, Band Aid, earth. Just enough oil and body. Really enjoyable! || The very best blended malt I’ve come across globally, a proper whisky bottled at proper strength with no colouring || This is one of my favourites. I cannot believe how affordable this whisky is. To me, this brings me to a campfire at a ocean beach where I'm eating fruits. The nose is amazing. The taste and finish are really good. I wouldn't call this overly peaty at all. If anything, it's more sea-brine than smoke. They are really nicely balanced. Thinking about it makes my mouth water. I keep reaching forward financially to find something that engages me a little more. It looks like I need to spend about 4x the money for a bottle that is more enjoyable (to me).

name: Collectivum XXVIIISpecial Releases 2017
characters: Dark Chocolate, Lemon, Cinnamon, Smoke, Orange, Apple
nose: Surprisingly mild in feel. The overall aroma is tightly integrated: spicy-sweet and fruity, combining spiky green leaves and dog roses with autumnal forests, toffee and rich vanilla sauce. The greenness comes to dominate, although the sour notes are tempered by sweet brown butter and a slice of candied fruit. Time reveals more herbal notes, with minty toffee and hints of pastry. Water opens all this up, drying and introducing Speyside notes of the sweetshop, with candy and dried apple rings joined by floral touches.
palate: A balance of sweetness, acidity and tannic dryness. Nuts and spice lead, with hazelnuts and almonds joined by bitter walnuts and hot cinnamon. Sweetness builds behind, with candy, barley sugar and sharp candied lemons. The almonds reappear, now sugared, only to disappear amid more citrus, tempered by toffee and fudge spiced with cinnamon, and finally by fruity dark chocolate. Water cools; the smooth sweetness and spice rise, bringing a refreshing bitter note; cream, apple sauce and milk chocolate laced with oak, clove and dark chocolate.
finish: Of medium-length, with buttery pastry, warming spice and a thin layer of sharp fruit; a fresh apple pie ready for the oven. The fruit lingers as apple skin, joined by crisp pear.
reviews: This is possibly the best value whisky I have encountered in decades; closest to a top Brora costing 20 to 30 times the price, touching on all the range that this vaunted and shuttered distillery musters. Of course this is a blend of multiple regions, but you suspect with micro contributions from many and large contributions from a few, particularly leading with a wonderful Clynelish (sibling distillery of the defunct Brora), and a masterfully light backing of an Islay, amongst others. This has a wonderful soaring range. I have both held and participated in single-malt whisky flights with many; this has had only rave responses, and from a wonderfully obscure and very cost-effective blend, that carries itself like an apex lightly-peated highland single-malt. I suspect the unorthodox story and lack of any historical reference lead to what I see as a deep discount, but also make this a wonderful “discovery”. When price and quality come together, I will buy for future years, and have happily loaded up on this one-off to the full extent my budget and conscience would let me. Just brilliant. || A lovely perfumed nose, and then spice, a bit of heat, some smoke, and lots of other things going on and great length. Really lovely whisky, I like a lot! || Superb and complex whisky. Maybe needs drop of water to fully appreciate the taste. Perfect option if you are tired of binary selection of peated/unpeated whisky. || Exceptional whisky || Great whisky
_text_all: dark chocolate lemon cinnamon smoke orange apple partridge fondue dim sum surprisingly mild in feel the overall aroma is tightly integrated spicy-sweet and fruity combining spiky green leaves and dog roses with autumnal forests toffee and rich vanilla sauce the greenness comes to dominate although the sour notes are tempered by sweet brown butter and slice of candied fruit time have both held and participated in single-malt whisky flights with many this has had only rave responses and from wonderfully obscure and very cost-effective blend that carries itself like an apex lightly-peated highland single-malt suspect the unorthodox story and lack of any historical reference lead to what see as deep discount but also make this wonderful discovery when price and quality come together will buy for future years and have happily loaded up on this one-off to the full extent my budget and conscience would let me just brilliant lovely perfumed nose and then spice bit of heat some smoke and lots of other things going on and great length really lovely whisky like lot superb and complex whisky maybe needs drop of water to fully appreciate the taste perfect option if you are tired of binary selection of peated unpeated whisky exceptional whisky great whisky

name: Berry Bros & Rudd Islay Blended Malt
palate: Full, approachable, creamy texture with some sweetness, and the quick reminder of its smoky heritage.
reviews: I thought for the price this is a really nice whisky. I'd suspect its mostly quite young spirits in the mix but still has a decent amount of flavour and finish to be satisfying. Compared to the 'special' releases from the big players at a similar price point I'd take the BBR every time.
_text_all: apple pear smoke tar cream no description full approachable creamy texture with some sweetness and the quick reminder of its smoky heritage long lingering peat smoke thought for the price this is really nice whisky suspect its mostly quite young spirits in the mix but still has decent amount of flavour and finish to be satisfying compared to the special releases from the big players at similar price point take the bbr every time

name: Scallywag Speyside Blended Malt
main_info: speyside blended malt scotch whiskydouglas laing
characters: Malt, Orange, Oil, Lemon, Apple, Cinnamon
nose: Sweet and grainy on the nose, with freshly milled malt, porridge made with water, lemon zest, orange peel, redcurrants and a hint of woody spice.
palate: Soft and oily, with some spice on the front of the tongue and developing richness - more porridge, tangy lemon sherbert, lemon bonbons, stewed apples with cinnamon, caraway seeds and a hint of sour fruit.
finish: Medium-length with apples, apple skin, spice and pastry cases.
reviews: Fruity and spicy. Quite a dry taste but overall excellent whisky. I received this as a gift and wouldn’t have bought it myself as I hate dogs! || A bit disappointing. As other reviewers have said, elements of iodine and smoke. Most un-Speyside. A little bitter and short on the palate too. Was expecting much more || Excellent value for money - this is beautiful, full bodied Malt. Worth every penny as this is a thoroughly, thoroughly enjoyable dram || Really excellent and exciting whisky. This is a great Speyside whisky with a character and depth in abundance. A great balance of malt and barley and chocolatey spice. very much recommend. || Nose, Iodine. Palate, smoke and little else. Finish, peat. Nothing like a traditional speyside, no fruits, xmas cake, sherry et al. Very disappointing indeed.
_text_all: malt orange oil lemon apple cinnamon sweet and grainy on the nose with freshly milled malt porridge made with water lemon zest orange peel redcurrants and hint of woody spice soft and oily with some spice on the front of the tongue and developing richness - more porridge tangy lemon sherbert lemon bonbons stewed apples with cinnamon caraway seeds and hint of sour fruit medium-length with apples apple skin spice and pastry cases fruity and spicy quite dry taste but overall excellent whisky received this as gift and wouldn have bought it myself as hate dogs bit disappointing as other reviewers have said elements of iodine and smoke most un-speyside little bitter and short on the palate too was expecting much more excellent value for money - this is beautiful full-bodied malt worth every penny as this is thoroughly thoroughly enjoyable dram really excellent and exciting whisky this is great speyside whisky with character and depth in abundance great balance of malt and barley and chocolatey spice very much recommend nose iodine palate smoke and little else finish peat nothing like traditional speyside no fruits xmas cake sherry et al very disappointing indeed

name: Shackleton Blended Malt
characters: Vanilla, Brioche, Cinnamon, Sultana, Ginger, Pineapple
nose: Vanilla, toffee apple, brioche, Manuka honey and hints of marmalade followed by cinnamon, banana bread and ginger cake.
palate: Treacle toffee, Demerara sugar and sweet sultanas, glazed pineapple, freshly baked crusted bread and mango cake.
finish: Hot mulled wine, praline chocolate and oolong tea with a final whisper of gentle bonfire smoke and crème brûlée.
reviews: Very smooth blended whisky. Nice with a single cube of ice or a quality sparkling water. Never tire of this slightly sweet notes on the initial end. || I generally rotate between three whiskies. Tamnavulin, Laphroaig and Shackleton. I never get tired of Shackleton. I do though get bored at times with the others. || Very nice blended malt.. My current favourite, have had a few bottles of this.. I will be back. Smooth finish.. Ideal with  ice or a splash of water. || Probably best on a cold winteres evening, very pleasant tast with a warm after taste... definitely one for the colder months! || Slight edge of spice initial taste the finishing sweeter notes of tropical fruits. For a blended malt for £18 worth a punt . Well done Richard Patterson on this affordable Scotch.

name: Big Peat
characters: Smoke, Dark Chocolate, Pine, Almond, Brine, Cinnamon
reviews: Simply awful, synthetic to the core, there is nothing to recommend this and I have no understanding how people can rate this in any way || Wow can't get over the light straw colouring, obviously as stated no added colouring. Big whiff of peat on the nosing with brine then the bonfire sensation on the palate with sweet notes of marzipan and almonds. Love it . Marks out of 100 . We'll deserved 91. || I liked big peat || Mycket bra lagom rökighet || Top Whisky. As is obvious, very smokey, but not harsh at all. Though i always add a dash of water to a dram. reviews: Fruity who likes light drinkable whiskey, although the strength is felt on the throat, don't expect anything special. name: Blended Malt 197150 Year Old 50th Anniversary
main_info: blended malt scotch whiskythe whisky exchange
characters: Honey, Wax, Lemon, Sultana, Mango, Pineapple
nose: Shortbread with honey and combs of beeswax. The shortbread becomes more buttery and spread with apple and sultana jam. Spiced vanilla sponge cake pokes out around the edges, balanced by unsweetened whipped cream and savoury vanilla.
palate: Soft fruit leads, with apples and pears joined by barely ripe mango, slightly crunchy pineapple and fruit jelly sweets. Vanilla cream rolls in, followed by a dusting of baking spice. Wax-polished oak sits underneath alongside sponge cake and buttered toast.
finish: Honey and beeswax are joined by sweet candied lemons and more buttered toast.

name: Rock Island
main_info: island blended malt scotch whiskydouglas laing
characters: Sage, Rosemary, Black Pepper, Liquorice root, Brine, Honey
nose: As fresh and invigorating as a walk on the seafront. Briney, cough sweets, liquorice, and fresh herbs (sage and rosemary).
palate: Richer than expected, with warming notes of black pepper, sea salt and ozone, as well as a hint of honeyed fruit. Good weight.
finish: The well-balanced peat acts as a seabreak to the subtle but welcome fruit.
reviews: Sweet smoke with a long finish. Not a light dram but surprisingly sweet at the end. || Quite unique but nothing special about this one. I don't regret buying it but wouldn't buy it again, however I am still inclined to try the more expensive age-labeled ones due to the "uniqueness" of this brand.
_text_all: sage rosemary black pepper liquorice root brine honey as fresh and invigorating as walk on the seafront briney cough sweets liquorice and fresh herbs sage and rosemary richer than expected with warming notes of black pepper sea salt and ozone as well as hint of honeyed fruit good weight the well-balanced peat acts as seabreak to the subtle but welcome fruit sweet smoke with long finish not light dram but surprisingly sweet at the end quite unique but nothing special about this one don regret buying it but wouldn buy it again however am still inclined to try the more expensive age-labeled ones due to the uniqueness of this brand

name: Cladach Blended MaltSpecial Releases 2018
characters: Brine, Smoke, Apple, Black Pepper, Orange, Lemon
nose: Pink shrimp sweets and leather to start, with smoke slowly building behind. Fresh sea air and crashing waves sit alongside earthy peat and maritime-tinged smoke. Meaty barbecue notes develop.
palate: Peat leads but is quickly pushed to the back. The whisky is built around a sweet centre of boiled sweets and apple sauce, surrounded by salt and freshly-ground black pepper. A tingle of sherbet leads to zesty waxed lemons and sweet orange.
finish: Sweet peat and grass with a touch of char.
reviews: Volcanic blended malt with a salty, seaweed start and a long smoky finish || It’s hard to argue with the tasting notes above. And do not worry about this being a blend - it is a superb dram. The thing that really got me, was the smoothness. At 57% my throat should have been tingling... but no. No water required for this beauty. A rare sight in any bar so had to try it.... and was not disappointed. Absolutely stunning.
_text_all: brine smoke apple black pepper orange lemon pink shrimp sweets and leather to start with smoke slowly building behind fresh sea air and crashing waves sit alongside earthy peat and maritime-tinged smoke meaty barbecue notes develop peat leads but is quickly pushed to the back the whisky is built around sweet centre of boiled sweets and apple sauce surrounded by salt and freshly-ground black pepper tingle of sherbet leads to zesty waxed lemons and sweet orange sweet peat and grass with touch of char volcanic blended malt with salty seaweed start and long smoky finish it hard to argue with the tasting notes above and do not worry about this being blend - it is superb dram the thing that really got me was the smoothness at my throat should have been tingling but no no water required for this beauty rare sight in any bar so had to try it and was not disappointed absolutely stunning

name: Speyside Region 197343 Year Old Whisky Agency for TWE
main_info: speyside blended malt whiskythe whisky agency
nose: Spiced brioche, brown sugar and rich lardy cake. Cinnamon buns and iced Danish pastries with a cherry on the top. Fruit jelly notes develop – lemon, lime and pineapple – with a background of old, wax-polished oak tables. Meatier notes slowly emerge, balanced by sugar flowers, candied lemon and sweet whipped cream.
palate: Creamily textured, with lightly spiced egg-custard tarts leading into old Chartreuse, spiced sponge cake and butter cream – the herbal notes float around on top, while underneath sit piles of cakes and oaty biscuits. In between are fruity boiled sweets, barley sugar and herbal throat sweets. Tarte tatin notes develop, softly spiced and drenched with butter.
finish: Apple sauce and buttered toast. Toasted, spiced, fruit loaf develops. Apple sweets and cream remain.
reviews: Lucky enough to have tried this exceptional whisky recently, and must say for it to be blended, it is far superior to most 40+year single malts I have tried over the years. A full 10/10 to whomever is responsible for this blend. Superb. || Amazing dram. Complexity, waxiness, citrus fruits, tropical fruits, polish and an amazing, long finish || Fantastic dram, elegant and complex – a real stunner. || Stunning – another Speyside that hits every mark. || Really great stuff, as good or better than most of the other 73s I have tasted and this one is actually more reasonably priced than most. Get it while you can.
_text_all: no description spiced brioche brown sugar and rich lardy cake cinnamon buns and iced danish pastries with cherry on the top fruit jelly notes develop lemon lime and pineapple with background of old wax-polished oak tables meatier notes slowly emerge balanced by sugar flowers candied lemon and sweet whipped cream creamily textured with lightly spiced egg-custard tarts leading into old chartreuse spiced sponge cake and butter cream the herbal notes float around on top while underneath sit piles of cakes and oaty biscuits in between are fruity boiled sweets barley sugar and herbal throat sweets tarte tatin notes develop softly spiced and drenched with butter apple sauce and buttered toast toasted spiced fruit loaf develops apple sweets and cream remain lucky enough to have tried this exceptional whisky recently and must say for it to be blended it is far superior to most year single malts have tried over the years full to whomever is responsible for this blend superb amazing dram complexity waxiness citrus fruits tropical fruits polish and an amazing long finish fantastic dram elegant and complex real stunner stunning another speyside that hits every mark really great stuff as good or better than most of the other have tasted and this one is actually more reasonably priced than most get it while you can

name: The Gauldrons Batch 1
main_info: campbeltown blended malt scotch whiskydouglas laing
nose: A dry saltiness with sweet cereal and a late hint of gentle peat smoke.
palate: Initially dry (beachy and maritime) warming to crunched sugar, barley and oak.
finish: Warmingly spiced, bringing puffs of smoke and rock pools with a dark sugar sweetness.
reviews: Single Cask Single Malts married together to create one of the most unique and wonderful drams I have had in a while. As I work in the industry I have tried my fair share of whisky and every so often you come across one that stands out, this is one of them. Rich and baked biscuit nose then delicate smoke and caramel on the palate.

name: Timorous Beastie Highland Blended Malt
main_info: highland blended malt scotch whiskydouglas laing
nose: Fresh and appley, with barley (malted and not), sweet butter and lemon. Some sour apple and sweet pear drop sneak in around the sides.
palate: Oily, with more butter and candied fruit. Some icing sugar and butter cream sweetness appear, with darkly sweet raisins and soft brown sugar.
finish: Gentle spice, a pinch of orchard fruit and some dark sugar notes.
reviews: This is a fabulous malt with a huge amount of complexity and interest. A great balance of sweetness and spice. Hugely recommend. || Pale gold in colour then sweet honey on the tongue. Abide a while and the complex spiceyness almost explodes! Definitely not Timourous, and a pure delight for our Burn’s Fest !! || Delicious, easy to drink with a lovely after taste. || Great blend - taste is an iffy thing for sure but to give my take on things I rate Lagavulin 16 year old as my single malt of choice followed by 10 year old laphroaig and then other similar single malts BUT I find Monkey Shoulder blended malt to be a great taste and the best buy for the money that I have yet to try - all this said I got the Timorous Beastie for Christmas and each time I try an ounce or so, neat and at room temperature, I am more impressed - and the bottle is positively overwhelming to see on my whisky shelf - I will definitely buy another, || Simply Devine! A great highland Malt and a new favourite for sure

name: Shackleton's DiscoveryMackinlay's Rare Old Highland Malt
reviews: I bought 3 of these back in 2014. I took one to Antarctica in 2015, where my brother and I opened a bottle on the Antarctic Peninsular, 100 years after Shackleton was last there. One is still unopened and will stay that way. The other is used for special occasions. I top it up from the standard bottles that are still available on sale. A better whiskey than I imagined for a blend. Watch Richard Patterson on YouTube where he tells you how to drink it and it'll change your whisky drinking technique for life. I give it 5 stars because of the history. Just drinking it takes me back 100 years. || A great re-creation, smooth, full flavor. Have been saving 3 bottles for a special occasion, but incredibly, was able to have a couple of drams this spring when I was in Punta Arenas, Chile (Patagonia/Straits of Magellan) in the Shackleton Bar, Hotel Jos? Nogueira. History at two levels! Excellent taste and flavor. || awesome, Macallan 18yr old and this are unbeatable, Shackleton has been one of my motivational hero's so ive had to drink 5 bottles after an endurance event, still have 2 left. best time to drink it is when it snows and in front of an outdoor fire pit || Very good. I was expecting this to not be very good value, given the history attached to the whisky creation and the outstanding blended malts in this price bracket that it would compete with. Very balanced, integrated and complex with a hot finish. || Totally not at all like the one at Channing's. If you ever get the chance to actually taste the real thing , there is NO comparing as to the ultimate smoothness and the lasting peaty of the original. I guess I will have to go back to Scotland...

name: Chivas Century Of Malts
reviews: I had a bottle of this when it first came out some twenty years ago and loved it then. The little booklet it came with written by none other than Jim Murray was also fun. Was lucky enough to find another bottle last year gathering dust on a shelf here in Tokyo for 10,000 (£70 or $90). I drink from it sparingly, but always enjoy the experience. Unsurprisingly there's a lot going on in the glass and I find different notes with each sip. It always surprises me how harmoniously this vatted malt is, and I kind of dig the fact that I've technically drunk the distillate of all 100 distilleries, especially ones like Banff, Brechin/North Port, Dallas Dhu, Glen Albyn, Glen Mhor, Kinclaith, Ladyburn etc which are either impossible to find or prohibitively expensive if you can. Unfortunately this is the last glass (until I find another steal). Slainte. || Have been bought this as a Christmas present,a Wonderfull drinking experience,thankyou son! || I love this whisky and the cheeky way you can say you have tasted almost all the singlemalts! || hi I purchased a few bottles at the time and tried one, delicious!!still have a few bottles that I might sell one day for the right price || It is ok...nose just a confused mess, but the pallet is nice, finish is short and sweet...not bad, but not worth the price ransom ebayers want for it. 84/100

name: Serendipity 12 Year Old
reviews: I can confirm this was an accident as I was working at the Glenmorangie bottling plant at the time, and they also bottle Glen Moray, Ardbeg amongst others. Basically there was some of one product still in the vats when the other had been started, therefore mixing both. Only option is to bottle it so it doesn''t surprise me its happened before and im sure it wasn''t a stunt as the bottles were sold for a very fair price in the factory shop only (as far as I knew) hope this clears up any mysteries || Ive a bottle half empty and one unopened. Its delightful || I've tasted it and it is heavenly. I || "Seriously though.. how would Glen Moray even end up close to an Ardbeg vat?" ... from the time when Glen Moray and Ardbeg had the same owner and were bottled in the same plant.Probably originally intended to be a last batch of the Ardbeg 17yo. Whether accidental or deliberate, I like the result a lot. 40% and lowish peat will disappoint the peatheads. But if you are just sitting with a glass of this on its own, it is a lovely, complex and quite gentle dram. || Seriously though.. how would Glen Moray even end up close to an Ardbeg vat?

name: Famous Grouse 30 Year Old
reviews: This is very dark, concentrated and delicious. For me, it may be a bit much at times, so I find myself adding a few drops to round up a relatively younger, more vibrant whiskey, such as the Glenlivet Archive 21 yo. If you happen to have both on hand, I encourage you to give it a try, it`s quite spectacular. || Karl, Dave and Amy Locke just returned from Scotch Distillery tour of Scotland. We went to dozens of distilleries. Probably, one of the finest whiskys that we have ever tasted is the Famous Grouse 30 year. We brought 4 bottles home with us. We have just completed an order for 6 more bottles from the Whisky Exchange. We received our order within a week.

name: Jameson 23 Year Old Small BatchExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Raisins, White Pepper, Toffee, Apple, Pear, Cashew
nose: Apples, pears and unripe nectarines leading vanilla cream, polished oak and spiced shortbread. Exotic notes of sour physalis and sweet papaya build, joined by more shortbread and a slice of lemon drizzle cake.
palate: Rich and oily spirit with toffee and vanilla cream chased by layers of fruit: sour apples and unripe pears, crisp sweet green apples and just-ripe pears, green mango, papaya, pineapple and gummi bears. Spiced sponge cake and light fruitcake develops along with wax-polished oak and hints of fruity dark chocolate.
finish: Spicy oak slowly fades to leave aniseed balls, apple sauce and crisp pear.

name: Connemara Peated Irish Whiskey
nose: Okay, well the smoke will not go unnoticed on the palate, but it is so clean, and surrounded by floral sweetness, that to compare it to a Scottish whisky would not quite be fair (to either). Peated barley at the heart of the flavours, grassy, and increasingly drying. Oak and almonds.
finish: A unique peated whiskey experience. Very drinkable, even quaff-able, with sweetness, and an interesting summer weeds type of presence. And plenty of peat, but don't expect a peat beast; this is driving-through-the-country window-seat-peat.
reviews: Lucky enough to have seen a bottle in a ferry duty-free. So glad to have enjoyed some of its most enjoyable flavours. || Very good single malt whiskey !its smoky touch of Irish peat! it lacks a little power around 48°! I love it ! || I have been a malt fan for many of my 80 years, the single malt that I like the best is Connemara peated ,I brought my first bottle while staying near Kilkee ,county Clare, fortunately for me I have found a supplier near to me in Cornwall, so I can always smile !! || Great peaty whiskey from Ireland. || No, my usual drink is Tollamore Dew! But I’m interested in trying this. Thank You

name: Green Spot
main_info: single pot still irish whiskeydistillery bottling
nose: Toffee and malt dominate, but still rather lean and clean, with a smattering of apple and pear.
palate: Soft on the palate, with chewy maltiness, and gentle fruit.

reviews: Excellent whiskey tried it on holiday and was delighted with it and I'm scottish || Incredible Smooth drink || Great whiskey, would highly recommend || Top notch, very smooth, only redbreast can be better || I started my whiskey journey with the well known Irish brands but then moved to Scotch and found myself liking the smoky and peaty affairs which was my preference.. Seen this as a recommendation so I thought I'd try it and boy, what a surprise. Crisp green apples on the nose also on initial tasting moving to a toffee/bourbon/minty affair smoothing out to vanilla. Finish is quite short for me, but that's not a minus. My new favourite!
_text_all: malt toffee apple pear toffee and malt dominate but still rather lean and clean with smattering of apple and pear soft on the palate with chewy maltiness and gentle fruit quite short but lovely balance between the fruit and malt excellent whisky tried it on holiday and was delighted with it and scottish incredible smooth drink great whisky would highly recommend top notch very smooth only redbreast can be better started my whisky journey with the well known irish brands but then moved to scotch and found myself liking the smoky and peaty affairs which was my preference seen this as recommendation so thought try it and boy what surprise crisp green apples on the nose also on initial tasting moving to toffee bourbon minty affair smoothing out to vanilla finish is quite short for me but that not minus my new favourite

name: Jameson Black Barrel
characters: Nutmeg, Dried Fruit, Oak, Malt, Honey, Apple
nose: Soft barrel-char aromas, along with sweet barley and cereal.
palate: Very soft and smooth. Subtle spiciness and barrel char comes through, along with fresh fruitiness.
reviews: If I could give,I would give 3,8 stars out of 5. It's character is hmmm... Round and smooth. If you like whisky with strong flavours,this is not for you,but if you like whisky without strong taste,this is for you. || Very nice and fresh, long glass with ice & giger ale. South America summer! || A very nice sweet fruity Irish profile. This New Years we did a comparison tasting of bushmills, powers red label, green spot, Jamesons black barrel, yellow spot and redbreast 12. This was solidly right in the middle of the pack. Not as good as. Ice as yellow spot or redbreast but a great value. || On the nose I get raisins, dates ,sweet Sherry & oak . Definitely it’s spent most of its time in Sherry barrels, it’s got just enough burn it’s not as smooth as I would have liked it’s quite young maybe 4- 5 years old , but the finish is long and enjoyable. Definitely Jameson’s are tapping into the Bourbon market. And you know what!! it reminds me of Black Bush. Which is also Sherry cask . And them guys have been producing that stuff for ever. I’m tempted to get a bottle of Black Bush to compare, but from my memory I seem to think Black Bush is a little more refined I could be wrong though. but I do know it’s more affordable but probably not as popular right now. || Feck its good

name: Sexton Single Malt Irish Whiskey
reviews: As an Ulsterman in exile I have been a Bushmills fan for most of my adult life(72), always been a fan of Black Bush and the matured variations but this liquid amber has stolen the show for me. || I tried this in an advent calendar. It is true that it is very smooth. However, some mention its sweetness, which, as a Speyside lover, I have not detected. I enjoy both Dailuaine, as well as Talisker - both in their own ways quite character-full - and that is what I find lacking in this sample. || Tried this over ice. A large one of course. As described. A lovely wee dram. Alex H, You are right about the bottle :) || Pleasantly surprised. I rather enjoy Peat Whiskey however this one has been really enjoyable. Excellent over ice or a splash of water. Extremely smooth. A lovely sweet honey taste on the end. Coming around the £30 this is definitely value for money. My only gripe is bottle design it's not very friendly in pouring but that is me being critical. || Very nice smooth Irish malt. The Best !

name: Redbreast 12 Year Old
reviews: Back again for another bottle of this very special Irish single pot still whiskey. I've been a dedicated follower of Scottish single malts for over 40 years. I have my favourites but decided to branch out and try the single pot still whiskeys. I'm delighted I did. I now have a range of the 'Spot' whiskeys, all delightful but the 12 year old Redbreast stands out. A very approachable and easy to drink whiskey. Received with the usual care and efficiency I have come to expect from TWE over many years.

name: Powers Irish Rye
characters: Orange, White Pepper, Cherry, Ginger, Honey, Vanilla
reviews: I've tried a few American and Canadian rye whiskies now, my favourite being Sazerac. Powers' Irish Rye doesn't seem inferior in comparison to any of them, is quite drinkable, nice and spicy, but from my experience the only definitive way to compare is to have a few of them on the go and blind taste them, which I've done with some Single Pot Still whiskies. I'd definitely buy this again || On the flavour to price ratio this is a win || As I'm writing this review, I'm sipping a glass of Jack Daniel's Rye ( I bought at Duty-Free ( U.S.) in January,2024 ).Rye is a U.S. ( and Canadian ) classic whiskey. Now, JD is new to the Rye Business ( and not near close to a No.1 Rye ).Powers Rye is a very poor Rye example ..insipid/weak...Ireland Calling ! || A light-bodied rye that is actually quite delicate and intricate in flavour as the charred-cask effect is not noticeable, unlike in US rye whiskies. name: Redbreast 19 Year OldOloroso Sherry Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cherry, Vanilla, Prunes, Dark Chocolate, Honey, Oak
nose: Weighty and rich with layers of fruit: plump sultanas, dried apricots and baked apples leading to cherries and berries. Pot-still spice and green leaves hide underneath along with cinder toffee and sandalwood.
palate: Intense fruit to start, wrapped in a spicy oak overcoat. Apples and pears with a touch of mango and pineapple cake, all followed by sultanas and raisins. Baking spice and toffee notes build.
reviews: Not as smooth as the 21 year old, but still a great whisky. Exceedingly fast shipping! || 12 year old Irish whiskey with toasted oak and sherry undertones. It makes me so happy.

name: Redbreast Lustau Edition
characters: Marzipan, Liquorice root, Sherry, Prunes, Figs
nose: Rich infusion of dark fruits, prunes, dates and figs with liquorice, marzipan, toasted oak and Redbreast spices.
finish: Endless. Sweetness and pot-still spices endure while oloroso sherry and Spanish oak have the last word.
reviews: At the price point this is simply outstanding. You could easily break the £100 mark and find far worse. More excellent stuff from Redbreast || I had bottle bought me for Birthday it’s absolutely lovely only problem didn’t last long enough lol . I Recommend to everyone one who loves whiskey. || Very smooth, sweet but not overpowering sweetness, nice cherry hint || Very smooth. No after bite. I can drink this product without any problems. || Remember the first time you sampled Redbreast (neat - obviously)? That first encounter with one of the finest expressions of the Irish pot still whiskey tradition lives long in the memory. There's the loving, silken mouthfeel as you roll it around as if your tongue, teeth and gums have encountered the rays of the evening sun somehow miraculously transmuted into a warming, golden liquid. Then comes the flavour which starts at the front of the mouth with hints of cinder toffee, candied peel and parma violets which segues as that first mouthful is slowly swallowed into walnuts and Dutch tobacco. Then the aftermath which is redolent of a walk through an orange grove just as the fruits are landing in the basket. And the sheer lusciousness of the experience as the sunshine slides into the soul and spreads out again, bringing joy and radiance to you and your companions. Remember what drinking Redbreast is like? Well, Redbreast Lustau edition is exactly like that. Only better.
_text_all: marzipan liquorice root sherry prunes figs rich infusion of dark fruits prunes dates and figs with liquorice marzipan toasted oak and redbreast spices no description endless sweetness and pot-still spices endure while oloroso sherry and spanish oak have the last word at the price point this is simply outstanding you could easily break the mark and find far worse more excellent stuff from redbreast had bottle bought me for birthday it absolutely lovely only problem didn last long enough lol recommend to everyone one who loves whisky very smooth sweet but not overpowering sweetness nice cherry hint very smooth no after bite can drink this product without any problems remember the first time you sampled redbreast neat - obviously that first encounter with one of the finest expressions of the irish pot still whisky tradition lives long in the memory there the loving silken mouthfeel as you roll it around as if your tongue teeth and gums have encountered the rays of the evening sun somehow miraculously transmuted into warming golden liquid then comes the flavour which starts at the front of the mouth with hints of cinder toffee candied peel and parma violets which segues as that first mouthful is slowly swallowed into walnuts and dutch tobacco then the aftermath which is redolent of walk through an orange grove just as the fruits are landing in the basket and the sheer lusciousness of the experience as the sunshine slides into the soul and spreads out again bringing joy and radiance to you and your companions remember what drinking redbreast is like well redbreast lustau edition is exactly like that only better

name: Powers John's Lane 12 Year OldSingle Pot Still
main_info: single pot still irish whiskeydistillery bottling
nose: Appealingly heady nose of candied orange peel and pot pourri - very fragrant and aromatic, with lightness of touch.
palate: The aromatic fruit continues on to the palate, with toasty spice. Good texture and balance.
finish: The light fruit makes way for the biscuity malt and subtle cinnamon-tinged spice.
reviews:
Lovely whiskey. As expected it is very similar to Redbreast 12 but at 46% has a bit more depth. They say it has more bourbon aged whiskey and that fits with the spice on the palate. This is a keeper. || Absolutely outstanding.  Love it || Absolutely the best Irish whiskey I’ve tried to date.
Much better than Red Breast or Green Spot.
Powers Gold is a strong runner up. || Chunky, rustic, real. || Delicious whiskey with long lasting, complex aftertones  of spice and oak. My absolute favourite. Richer than a Redbreast with a satisfying heat.
_text_all: orange toast biscuits cinnamon appealingly heady nose of candied orange peel and pot pourri - very fragrant and aromatic with lightness of touch the aromatic fruit continues on to the palate with toasty spice good texture and balance the light fruit makes way for the biscuity malt and subtle cinnamon-tinged spice lovely whisky as expected it is very similar to redbreast but at has bit more depth they say it has more bourbon aged whisky and that fits with the spice on the palate this is keeper absolutely outstanding love it absolutely the best irish whisky ve tried to date much better than red breast or green spot powers gold is strong runner up chunky rustic real delicious whisky with long lasting complex aftertones of spice and oak my absolute favourite richer than redbreast with satisfying heat

name: Jameson 22 Year Old Small BatchExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Milk Chocolate, Hazelnut, Apple, Mango, Nutmeg, Vanilla
nose: Chocolate dipped honeycomb with orange zest, charred oak and vanilla spice. Dried apricots with hints of ginger and nutmeg add to the array of aromas.
palate: More cooked white fruits, mango jam, papaya, dried apricots, golden sultanas, crème caramel, and chocolate fudge brownies with whipped cream. That nuttiness re-emerges with marzipan, nutmeg and ground ginger, green coffee beans, and a drop of imperial stout. The bourbon and sherry casks bring a great sense of richness and texture but they don’t overwhelm the fruity pot still whiskey at the core of the blend. Very nicely done.
finish: Long and oily with an earthiness that keeps the sweeter notes in balance. The tropical fruits come back at the end accompanied by warming spices.
_text_all: milk chocolate hazelnut apple mango nutmeg vanilla chocolate dipped honeycomb with orange zest charred oak and vanilla spice dried apricots with hints of ginger and nutmeg add to the array of aromas more cooked white fruits mango jam papaya dried apricots golden sultanas cr me caramel and chocolate fudge brownies with whipped cream that nuttiness re-emerges with marzipan nutmeg and ground ginger green coffee beans and drop of imperial stout the bourbon and sherry casks bring great sense of richness and texture but they don overwhelm the fruity pot still whisky at the core of the blend very nicely done long and oily with an earthiness that keeps the sweeter notes in balance the tropical fruits come back at the end accompanied by warming spices

name: Proper No. Twelve Blended Irish Whiskey
reviews: Tried our first bottle today. Of all the Irish whiskey I have tried this is ..one of the best single malt or blend I have drunk. Lovely easy sipping whiskey with great balanced flavours. || The description has it spot on... || harsh and brash. all style and no substance. bottle looks fancy but the actual product is inferior and overblown. unpleasant taste as it decelops, quite a snappy finish though. Best consumed with vast amounts of coke, works ok with soft drinks too || We Loved it but was a bit miffed that the advert showed the Bottle in a lovely wooen xmas jumper, but ours did not. || Horrible, harsh, an absolute sham of a whisky, drop the celebrity endorsement and this wouldn't make a bottom shelf blend.

name: Green Spot Chateau Montelena Zinfandel Finish
nose: Crisp oak combines with the soft sweetness of vanilla, white chocolate and marshmallow, balanced with signature Green Spot red apples and ripe pears, along with pomegranate, cranberries and maraschino cherries, the contribution of the wine cask
palate: Sweet mouth coating takes on a dry note thanks to the effect of the wine cask. Pot still spices subside with zesty citrus leading to ripe orchard fruit and red berries. A touch of marzipan and toasted oak add to the complexity
reviews: A gift from Dublin when my wife returned recently. I had never tried a Greenspot whiskey before. I have to say I am very impressed with this one. Great spicy flavours, very smooth and extremely easy to drink. I will be adding this to my list of favourites! || I bought a bottle after reading the reviews and I’m slightly disappointed with it. I thought it would be as good as the Redbreast Single Pot Still 12 years old. But I’m glad I bought it as a part of my collection. || I like the standard Green Spot and was keen to see if this finish added anything. It did. This version is even better and I’d recommend it, particularly to people who have maybe tried one or two Irish whiskies but didn’t find something in them to encourage them to try more || An extremely good irish. Not harsh in the nose, but creamy and almost butterscotchy if that can be a word. The cream is there on the pallate. Easy drinking, yes yes yes.

name: Glendalough Double Barrel Single Grain
nose: Slight but undoubtedly rich with dark fruit; cherry, raisin, fig (with Christmas pudding notes on the nose for those lucky enough to know what that is) along with floral lemongrass and a touch of nutmeg.
palate: Sweet and creamy on the palate, with butterscotch, honey and peppercorn bringing along sweet Bourbon Cask notes with dried fruit returning through notes of maraschino cherries and a pinch of brown sugar.
finish: Lingering notes of ginger spices with a faint glimmer of almond to end a complex Irish Whiskey from start to finish.
reviews: Low in vanilla compared with what you'd expect from bourbon barrels but otherwise the description is accurate and for the money this is a surprisingly complex and extremly enjoyable whiskey. Sweetness level is just right too. 5 stars for a £30 whiskey. || Dry tasting but has a sweet aftertaste. Great body and flavour || This is a fantastic whiskey, smell and taste very typical of pot still whiskies so if you're a fan this will not disappoint. For the price you pay this is a steal! || Good whisky for the money. Nothing special or extraordinary, smooth ant definitely not Irish taste. || Smooth and sweet, full and friendly this is a fantastic friend! Description of the nose, palate and finish are quite accurate.
_text_all: no description slight but undoubtedly rich with dark fruit cherry raisin fig with christmas pudding notes on the nose for those lucky enough to know what that is along with floral lemongrass and touch of nutmeg sweet and creamy on the palate with butterscotch honey and peppercorn bringing along sweet bourbon cask notes with dried fruit returning through notes of maraschino cherries and pinch of brown sugar lingering notes of ginger spices with faint glimmer of almond to end complex irish whisky from start to finish low in vanilla compared with what you expect from bourbon barrels but otherwise the description is accurate and for the money this is surprisingly complex and extremly enjoyable whisky sweetness level is just right too stars for whisky dry tasting but has sweet aftertaste great body and flavour this is fantastic whisky smell and taste very typical of pot still whiskies so if you re fan this will not disappoint for the price you pay this is steal good whisky for the money nothing special or extraordinary smooth ant definitely not irish taste smooth and sweet full and friendly this is fantastic friend description of the nose palate and finish are quite accurate

name: Teeling Single Grain Whiskey
characters: Toffee, Leaves, Mixed Herb, Cinnamon, Butter, Wine
nose: Meaty and sweet with bitter tannins, sweet toffee, fudge, green leaves, dried mixed herbs dark chocolate, marmalade and anise.
palate: Toffee, spice (cinnamon and nutmeg), orchard fruit, grape skin, polished oak and butterscotch.
finish: Grape skin and red wine tannic touches, with spiced butter and shortbread.
reviews: Really enjoyed this Irish single grain whisky, I would go as far to say one of the best single grain whiskies I've ever had, and adding water only helps elevate the experience. Certainly helps being a hight alcoholic strength and non-chill filtered, solid 4.5 stars. || Yes I tried Teeling Single Grain Whiskey and would say one of the best whiskeys I ever tasted, it's fantastic || Excellent Irish Whiskey. As smooth as it gets! || Loved this. || A first class grain whiskey. Often thought of as the poor relative of the single malt but only fully appreciated when tasted. My first bottle will soon need replacing. Give it a go!

name: Redbreast 199725 Year Old Cream Sherry Cask The Whisky Exchange Exclusive
characters: Apple, Dark Chocolate, Orange, Thyme, Blackcurrant, Coffee
nose: Caramelised pecans, walnut liqueur, honey roasted cashews. Plums, figs, raisins and dried cranberries. There’s a green side that you sometimes find in old pot still whiskey with blackberry leaves, vine leaves and a little spearmint.
palate: Peanut brittle, a few dried chillis, some black peppercorns. Lots of umami with oxidised sherry notes, warm earth, dried shiitakes, barley miso, and cacao nibs. Then hazelnuts, liquorice, nutmeg, bitter oranges and crème de cassis. A dash of water brings out big chocolaty notes and more nutty sherry character.
finish: Long, with a nice tension between oak tannins and milk chocolate.
_text_all: apple dark chocolate orange thyme blackcurrant coffee caramelised pecans walnut liqueur honey roasted cashews plums figs raisins and dried cranberries there green side that you sometimes find in old pot still whisky with blackberry leaves vine leaves and little spearmint peanut brittle few dried chillis some black peppercorns lots of umami with oxidised sherry notes warm earth dried shiitakes barley miso and cacao nibs then hazelnuts liquorice nutmeg bitter oranges and cr me de cassis dash of water brings out big chocolaty notes and more nutty sherry character long with nice tension between oak tannins and milk chocolate

nose: Mown hay and cracked black pepper. Red bell peppers, nutmeg, clove oil and green tea. Sweet honey & peaches from the Malaga casks
palate: Honey sweetness with pot still spices. Flavours of fresh coffee, creamy milk chocolate and Crème Brûlée. Notes of red apples and toasted oak. Its finish is sophisticated and complex with a sweetness throughout, followed by a mix of red grape and dry barley upon exit
finish: The sweet spice persists after the soft fruit disappears.

name: Jameson
nose: Mellow pot still whiskey with toasted wood and sherry undertones.
reviews: I have lived in Ireland for few years and had Jameson on many occasions, I had a tour of Jameson distillery in Bow Street, Dublin. For some reason I never thought much of this whiskey, I was more of a Bushmills drinker. I bought a bottle last year and I was very surprised. This whisky is quite mellow, not very light- but quite smooth, lots of toffee, vanilla, milk chocolate, buttery flavor. You can taste the presence of maize- that's right!- as one of ingredients. Very enjoyable on ice. This is a great buy in this price range, to me way better than Bushmills Original. || Smooth raisins at a great price. || I started off my whisky journey some years back with Glenmorangie, which I still regularly drink. This was my first time drinking Jameson, I only got it because it was on offer, and thought being Irish I'd try an Irish stable. Wow so underwhelming. Practically no finish, I had to double check I'd drunk some. Trying to figure out the nose, all I got seemed like ethanol, and the hit of my stomach the next day was reminiscent of knacker drinking Southern Comfort in my teenage years. Definitely won't be buying again. Think I'll try getting a bottle of Tyrconnell single malt next time instead.. || Vanilla nose which continues through. Very smooth but packs an afterburn. Doesn’t have a complex mix of tastes. Satisfying nonetheless. Very short finish, tempting you to pour another one! || Consistently delicious and value for money whisky. At the beginning of the end of the world, as the sirens began to wail, I think I'd reach for this one.
_text_all: oak toast sherry mellow pot still whisky with toasted wood and sherry undertones no description incredibly smooth have lived in ireland for few years and had jameson on many occasions had tour of jameson distillery in bow street dublin for some reason never thought much of this whisky was more of bushmills drinker bought bottle last year and was very surprised this whisky is quite mellow not very light- but quite smooth lots of toffee vanilla milk chocolate buttery flavor you can taste the presence of maize- that right - as one of ingredients very enjoyable on ice this is great buy in this price range to me way better than bushmills original smooth raisins at great price started off my whisky journey some years back with glenmorangie which still regularly drink this was my first time drinking jameson only got it because it was on offer and thought being irish try an irish stable wow so underwhelming practically no finish had to double check drunk some trying to figure out the nose all got seemed like ethanol and the hit of my stomach the next day was reminiscent of knacker drinking southern comfort in my teenage years definitely won be buying again think ll try getting bottle of tyrconnell single malt next time instead vanilla nose which continues through very smooth but packs an afterburn doesn have complex mix of tastes satisfying nonetheless very short finish tempting you to pour another one consistently delicious and value for money whisky at the beginning of the end of the world as the sirens began to wail think reach for this one

name: Powers Gold Distiller's Cut
reviews:
My favorite Irish whiskey by far. Visiting Ireland often for work, a local friend suggested it,& from the moment I tried it, I loved it. Unique potent taste that distinguishes it from other Irish whiskeys. Always have a bottle in my cellar || This is without doubt, (Distillers Cut) to the best whiskey I have ever tasted. I have for a long time been a drinker of Gold Label among others and never missed an opportunity to buy a bottle or two whenever I found it. My best friend who sadly died last year lived at Trallispean  Beach ( South of Baltimore) and whenever I visited him two or three times a year, always had a bottle of Gold Label on the mantle piece which he bought for my visits and affectionately described as “Holy water”
As long as this brand is available in England I will be buying and drinking it - I hope Tesco’s will continue stocking it

reviews: Very tasty whisky, intense and flavorful. Loses a star because it does show some sulfur notes, and it’s not something I like in whiskeys. It’s not off putting, and others may not even notice. I’d happily recommend this and will certainly be replacing this bottle when it’s over.

name: The Legendary Silkie Irish Whiskey
nose: Fresh and malty, brisk like green apples, opens to be more honeyed with a gentle butteryness.
reviews: Amazed that the review does not get the hint of smoke at the end and judges it zero on that. It's clearly there. A more interesting whiskey from this company, showing that they are learning. Leaving it at 46 percent allows for more interest as drops of water open up the different notes. A great effort from this distillery that is finally getting to make it's own products. || Myself and 2 friends drank the bottle earlier this week. We all thought it was very smooth and so drinkable, we will defo be buying this again. Also it doesn't taste like a 46% Whiskey, we would highly recommend this lovely Whiskey .

name: Teeling 199129 Year Old Rum Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Papaya, Pineapple, Mango, Honey, Lime, Oak
nose: Gummi bears and golden syrup with a pile of peelable citrus: tangerines, clementines and satsumas. Mango and pineapple notes develop: both fresh and dried. A background of golden syrup and honey adds extra sweetness and complexity.
palate: Fresh fruit leads: the mango and pineapple of the nose with extra guava and a touch of yuzu. Brown sugar sweetness hides underneath along with a touch of vanilla and soft spice.
finish: A touch of heat fades to leave jelly baby fruitiness, damp oak and gentle spice.

name: Teeling Single Malt Whiskey
characters: Dried Fruit, Vanilla, Lemon, Clove, Oak
nose: Vibrant with notes of melon, figs, toffee and lemon.
palate: More pineapple kubes, icing sugar, lemon bonbons and sponge cake with butter icing, with granny smith apples for some balancing sharpness and some cloves for bitterness and spice.
finish: Long with sweetness in harmony with dry tannins from the wood.
reviews: After visiting the Teeling distillery, listening tothe story and doing some tastings, i can conclude hands down that this single malt pot still is the soul of Dublin and one of my favourites. Oh, that finish!!! || This is my current go-to whiskey. The finish on this whiskey is the best I've ever experienced. I always buy a second bottle before the first is half gone. || Smooth and gentle. Good price point. Great for Saturday nights while watching a movie or reading a book. || Exceptionally smooth; will always keep a bottle on the top shelve. || Love it! For the price Jameson Caskmates kills it

name: McConnell's 5 Year Old Irish WhiskySherry Cask
nose: Dried Figs and currants followed by Christmas spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon, dark chocolate, and a hint of fresh leather.
palate: Demerara sugar, dark ripe cherries and black raspberry followed by bitter dark chocolate shavings and rich red apples.
finish: Lingering oak notes, with a hint of leather and subtle clove spice.
reviews: Love this Whisky! Top draw || Great Whisky straight from the bowels of the notorious Crumlin Prison. LOVE the Sherrywood || The jammy dark fruit flavours really stand out in this whisky, along with the almost savoury dark chocolate notes, with an unctousness beyond it's 5 years. Well worth a try.
_text_all: no description dried figs and currants followed by christmas spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon dark chocolate and hint of fresh leather demerara sugar dark ripe cherries and black raspberry followed by bitter dark chocolate shavings and rich red apples lingering oak notes with hint of leather and subtle clove spice love this whisky top draw great whisky straight from the bowels of the notorious crumlin prison love the sherrywood the jammy dark fruit flavours really stand out in this whisky along with the almost savoury dark chocolate notes with an unctousness beyond it years well worth try

name: Green Spot 201310 Year Old Bourbon Cask Exclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Vanilla, Pear, Apple, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Orange
nose: Layers of fruity apple: sour green, sweet red and green, and apple candy. Vanilla cream, buttery pastry and softly spiced apple-pie filling follow. The fruitiness continues with gummi bears and a touch of ripe pear. The vanilla becomes more complex, showing tonka bean florality, spice and coconut.
palate: Crisp fruit also leads on the palate, with the gummi bears reappearing and diving into a basket of apples. Spice builds, with cinnamon and nutmeg joined by anise and mint fondant. Sponge cake with candied peel and polished oak develops.
finish: Juicy apples, pears, mango and candied citrus, with gentle spice and gentle vanilla.
_text_all: vanilla pear apple cinnamon nutmeg orange layers of fruity apple sour green sweet red and green and apple candy vanilla cream buttery pastry and softly spiced apple-pie filling follow the fruitiness continues with gummi bears and touch of ripe pear the vanilla becomes more complex showing tonka bean florality spice and coconut crisp fruit also leads on the palate with the gummi bears reappearing and diving into basket of apples spice builds with cinnamon and nutmeg joined by anise and mint fondant sponge cake with candied peel and polished oak develops juicy apples pears mango and candied citrus with gentle spice and gentle vanilla

name: Method and Madness Hickory Wood FinishExclusive to The Whisky Exchange
characters: Cacao, Almond, Honeycomb, Caramel, Smoke, Dark Chocolate
nose: Immediately filled with aromas of candied bacon, sweet hickory smoke, honeycomb and pecan pie, the nose then brings heaps of caramelised apples, autumn leaves, slightly singed barbecued pineapple and burnt caramel.
palate: Ground ginger and cloves jump forward, followed by dried figs, stewed plums, savoury oak spice and far away bonfires. Green sticks, smoked almonds and dark chocolate build underneath.
finish: Lingering notes if rich mocha ice cream and treacle tart.
